{"eng": "By Philip Blenkinsop and Charlotte Van Campenhout\n\nBRUSSELS (Reuters) -The European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6% from Friday on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials said, ratcheting up tensions with Beijing in Brussels' largest trade case yet.\n\nThere is however a four-month window during which the tariffs are provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nThe European Commission's provi"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Beijing"}, "country": {"uri": "2024-07-411289397", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "13:14:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T13:14:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T13:14:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.dealstreetasia.com/stories/china-built-evs-duties-eu-402678", "title": "China-built EVs hit with duties in biggest EU trade case yet", "body": "The European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6% from Friday on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials said, ratcheting up tensions with Beijing in Brussels' largest trade case yet.\n\nThere is however a four-month window during which the tariffs are provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4% and 37.6% without backdating are designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen has said is a threatened flood of cheap EVs built with state subsidies.\n\nThe rates, laid out in a 208-page document published on Thursday, are almost the same as those announced by the Commission on June 12. The executive made adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nThese could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nEU trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said there is no basis for China to retaliate.\n\n\"Our aim is to ... ensure fair competition and a level playing field,\" he said in an interview with Bloomberg.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the Commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose definitive duties, typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\n\"Those talks with China are ongoing and indeed should a mutually beneficial solution emerge, we can also find ways not to apply at the end of the day the tariffs,\" Dombrovskis said.\n\n\"But it is very clear this solution (would) need to solve that market distortion that we are currently having ... and it needs to be market compliant.\"\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue.\n\n\"We hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD faces duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla and BMW, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6%.\n\nHIGHER PRICES\n\nChinese EV makers will have to decide whether to absorb the tariffs or raise their prices to cover the billions of dollars in new costs at European borders.\n\n\"Chinese automakers are desperate to expand their sales outside of China since the domestic price war is taking its toll,\" said Tu Le, founder of consultancy Sino Auto Insights.\n\nIncreased EV costs for European consumers would undermine the EU's goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050, opponents of the tariffs say.\n\nChinese brands MG and Nio suggested on Thursday they might raise prices in Europe later this year. Tesla said last month it planned to increase the prices of its Model 3.\n\nThe prospect of duties may spur Chinese automakers to invest in factories in Europe, although labour and manufacturing costs are higher than in China.\n\nOn Thursday, Xpeng became the latest EV maker to consider setting up manufacturing in the region to avoid the tariffs.\n\nEurope's biggest carmaker Volkswagen was swift to criticise Thursday's announcement.\n\n\"The negative effects of this decision outweigh any benefits for the European and especially the German automotive industry,\" a Volkswagen spokesperson said in a statement.\n\nAuto industry executives have warned against the tariffs, fearful of counter-measures that could affect the competitiveness of their cars in China where they are already struggling to keep up with a growing number of domestic competitors.\n\nGerman carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China.\n\nThe Commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025. It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nWAVERING EU SUPPORT\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed. The EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October.\n\nThe issue will be put to EU members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in the Commission's case, which is the first trade case of this kind.\n\nAlthough the Commission initiated its investigation without an industry complaint, members are wavering over whether to back the additional tariffs, highlighting Brussels' challenge in getting support for the case.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have a modest impact on the majority of Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.", "source": {"uri": "dealstreetasia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nWavering EU Support\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed. The EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October.\n\nThe issue will be put to EU members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in the additional tariffs, highlighting Brussels' challenge in getting support for the case.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have a modest impact on the majority of Chinese {"uri": "2024-07-411171780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "11:33:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T11:33:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T11:18:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.timeslive.co.za/motoring/news/2024-07-04-china-built-evs-hit-with-duties-in-biggest-eu-trade-case-yet/", "title": "China-built EVs hit with duties in biggest EU trade case yet", "body": "The EU will impose tariffs of up to 37.6% from Friday on imports of electric vehicles (EVs) made in China, EU officials said, ratcheting up tensions with Beijing in Brussels' largest trade case yet.\n\nThere is, however, a four-month window during which the tariffs are provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4% and 37.6% without backdating are designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen has said is a threatened flood of cheap EVs built with state subsidies.\n\nThe rates, laid out in a 208-page document published on Thursday, are almost exactly the same as those announced by the commission on June 12. The executive made slight adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nThese could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nEU trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said there is no basis for China to retaliate.\n\n\"Our aim is to ... ensure fair competition and a level playing field,\" he said in an interview with Bloomberg.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose \"definite duties\", typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\n\"Those talks with China are ongoing and should a mutually beneficial solution emerge we can also find ways not to apply the tariffs,\" Dombrovskis said.\n\n\"But it is clear this solution [would] need to solve that market distortion we have ... and it needs to be market compliant.\"\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs.\n\n\"We hope the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD will face duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed by the EU to have co-operated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla and BMW, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not co-operate a rate of 37.6%.\n\nEurope's biggest carmaker Volkswagen was swift to criticise Thursday's announcement.\n\n\"The negative effects of this decision outweigh any benefits for the European and especially the German automotive industry,\" a Volkswagen spokesperson said.\n\nAuto industry executives have warned against the tariffs, fearful of counter-tariffs or other measures that could affect the competitiveness of their cars in China when they are already struggling to keep up with a growing number of domestic competitors in the EV market.\n\nGerman carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China.\n\nThe commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025. It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed. The EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October.\n\nThe issue will be put to EU members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in the commission's case, which is the first trade case of this kind.\n\nThough the commission initiated its investigation without an industry complaint, members are wavering over whether to back the additional tariffs, highlighting Brussels' challenge in getting support for the case.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have a modest affect on most Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.", "source": {"uri": "timeslive.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": "Times LIVE"}, {"uri": "8209565916", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "12:50:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T12:50:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T12:49:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.zawya.com/en/world/china-and-asia-pacific/china-built-evs-hit-with-duties-in-biggest-eu-trade-case-yet-pnyapzc0", "title": "China-built EVs hit with duties in biggest EU trade case yet", "body": "BRUSSELS - The European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6% from Friday on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials said, ratcheting up tensions with Beijing in Brussels' largest trade case yet.\n\nThere is however a four-month window during which the tariffs are provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4% and 37.6% without backdating are designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen has said is a threatened flood of cheap EVs built with state subsidies.\n\nThe rates, laid out in a 208-page document published on Thursday, are almost the same as those announced by the Commission on June 12. The executive made adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nEU trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said there is no basis for China to retaliate.\n\n\"Our aim is to ... ensure fair competition and a level playing field,\" he said in an interview with Bloomberg.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the Commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose definitive duties, typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\n\"Those talks with China are ongoing and indeed should a mutually beneficial solution emerge, we can also find ways not to apply at the end of the day the tariffs,\" Dombrovskis said.\n\n\"But it is very clear this solution (would) need to solve that market distortion that we are currently having ... and it needs to be market compliant.\"\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue.\n\n\"We hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD 002594.SZ faces duties of 17.4%, Geely GEELY.UL 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla TSLA.O and BMW BMWG.DE, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6%.\n\nHIGHER PRICES\n\nChinese EV makers will have to decide whether to absorb the tariffs or raise their prices to cover the billions of dollars in new costs at European borders.\n\n\"Chinese automakers are desperate to expand their sales outside of China since the domestic price war is taking its toll,\" said Tu Le, founder of consultancy Sino Auto Insights.\n\nIncreased EV costs for European consumers would undermine the EU's goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050, opponents of the tariffs say.\n\nChinese brands MG and Nio 9866.HK suggested on Thursday they might raise prices in Europe later this year. Tesla said last month it planned to increase the prices of its Model 3.\n\nThe prospect of duties may spur Chinese automakers to invest in factories in Europe, although labour and manufacturing costs are higher than in China.\n\nOn Thursday, Xpeng 9868.HK became the latest EV maker to consider setting up manufacturing in the region to avoid the tariffs.\n\nEurope's biggest carmaker Volkswagen VOWG_p.DE was swift to criticise Thursday's announcement.\n\n\"The negative effects of this decision outweigh any benefits for the European and especially the German automotive industry,\" a Volkswagen spokesperson said in a statement.\n\nAuto industry executives have warned against the tariffs, fearful of counter-measures that could affect the competitiveness of their cars in China where they are already struggling to keep up with a growing number of domestic competitors.\n\nGerman carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China.\n\nThe Commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025. It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nWAVERING EU SUPPORT\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed. The EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October.\n\nThe issue will be put to EU members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in the Commission's case, which is the first trade case of this kind.\n\nAlthough the Commission initiated its investigation without an industry complaint, members are wavering over whether to back the additional tariffs, highlighting Brussels' challenge in getting support for the case.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have a modest impact on the majority of Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.\n\n(Reporting by Philip Blenkinsop, Charlotte Van Campenhout; Additional reporting by Victoria Waldersee in Berlin, Zhang Yan in Shanghai, Giulio Piovaccari in Milan, Gilles Gillaume and Richard Lough in Paris;Writing by Josephine MasonEditing by Catherine Evans and Barbara Lewis)", {"uri": "2024-07-411126921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:53:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:53:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T09:29:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/eu-imposes-duties-china-built-092952712.html", "title": "China-built EVs hit with duties in biggest EU trade case yet", "body": "By Philip Blenkinsop and Charlotte Van Campenhout\n\nBRUSSELS (Reuters) -The European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6% from Friday on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials said, ratcheting up tensions with Beijing in Brussels' largest trade case yet.\n\nThere is however a four-month window during which the tariffs are provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4% and 37.6% without backdating are designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen has said is a threatened flood of cheap EVs built state subsidies.\n\nThe rates, laid out in a 208-page document published on Thursday, are almost exactly the same as those announced by the Commission on June 12. The executive made slight adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nThese could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nEU trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said there is no basis for China to retaliate.\n\n\"Our aim is to ... ensure fair competition and level playing field,\" he said in an interview with Bloomberg.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the Commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose \"definite duties\", typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\n\"Those talks with China are ongoing and indeed should a mutually beneficial solution emerge, we can also find ways not to apply at the end of the day the tariffs,\" Dombrovskis said.\n\n\"But it is very clear this solution (would) need to solve that market distortion that we are currently having ... and it needs to be market compliant.\"\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue.\n\n\"We hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD will face duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed by the EU to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla and BMW, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6%.\n\nCRITICISM\n\nEurope's biggest carmaker Volkswagen was swift to criticise Thursday's announcement.\n\n\"The negative effects of this decision outweigh any benefits for the European and especially the German automotive industry,\" a Volkswagen spokesperson said in a statement.\n\nAuto industry executives have warned against the tariffs, fearful of counter-tariffs or other measures that could affect the competitiveness of their cars in China when they are already struggling to keep up with a growing number of domestic competitors in the EV market.\n\nGerman carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China.\n\nThe Commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025. It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nWAVERING EU SUPPORT\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed. The EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October.\n\nThe issue will be put to EU members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in the Commission's case, which is the first trade case of this kind.\n\nAlthough the Commission initiated its investigation without an industry complaint, members are wavering over whether to back the additional tariffs, highlighting Brussels' challenge in getting support for the case.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have a modest impact on the majority of Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.\n\n(Reporting by Philip Blenkinsop, Charlotte Van Campenhout; Additional reporting by Victoria Waldersee in Berlin and Richard Lough in Paris; Writing by Josephine MasonEditing by Catherine Evans and Barbara Lewis)", "source": {"uri": "ca.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! Finance"}, "authors": [{"uri": "philip_blenkinsop@ca.finance.yahoo.com", "name": "Philip Blenkinsop", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Tariff"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "European Union"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "8209369062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:43:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:43:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:42:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13600257/China-built-EVs-hit-duties-biggest-EU-trade-case-yet.html", "title": "China-built EVs hit with duties in biggest EU trade case yet", "body": "Intense negotiations likely to continue\n\n*\n\nBeijing has said will protect its interests\n\n*\n\nVolkswagen critical of EU announcement\n\n*\n\nTariffs are far lower than planned US tariffs\n\n(Adds trade chief comments in paragraphs 7, 8, 11 and 12, VW comment in 19, 20, background in 26 and 27)\n\nBy Philip Blenkinsop and Charlotte Van Campenhout\n\nBRUSSELS, July 4 (Reuters) - The European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6% from Friday on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials said, ratcheting up tensions with Beijing in Brussels' largest trade case yet.\n\nThere is however a four-month window during which the tariffs are provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4% and 37.6% without backdating are designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen has said is a threatened flood of cheap EVs built state subsidies.\n\nThe rates, laid out in a 208-page document published on Thursday, are almost exactly the same as those announced by the Commission on June 12. The executive made slight adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nThese could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nEU trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said there is no basis for China to retaliate.\n\n\"Our aim is to ... ensure fair competition and level playing field,\" he said in an interview with Bloomberg.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the Commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose \"definite duties\", typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\n\"Those talks with China are ongoing and indeed should a mutually beneficial solution emerge, we can also find ways not to apply at the end of the day the tariffs,\" Dombrovskis said.\n\n\"But it is very clear this solution (would) need to solve that market distortion that we are currently having ... and it needs to be market compliant.\"\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue.\n\n\"We hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD will face duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed by the EU to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla and BMW, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6%.\n\nCRITICISM\n\nEurope's biggest carmaker Volkswagen was swift to criticise Thursday's announcement.\n\n\"The negative effects of this decision outweigh any benefits for the European and especially the German automotive industry,\" a Volkswagen spokesperson said in a statement.\n\nAuto industry executives have warned against the tariffs, fearful of counter-tariffs or other measures that could affect the competitiveness of their cars in China when they are already struggling to keep up with a growing number of domestic competitors in the EV market.\n\nGerman carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China.\n\nThe Commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025. It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nWAVERING EU SUPPORT\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed. The EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October.\n\nThe issue will be put to EU members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in the Commission's case, which is the first trade case of this kind.\n\nAlthough the Commission initiated its investigation without an industry complaint, members are wavering over whether to back the additional tariffs, highlighting Brussels' challenge in getting support for the case.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have a modest impact on the majority of Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.\n\n(Reporting by Philip Blenkinsop, Charlotte Van Campenhout; Additional reporting by Victoria Waldersee in Berlin and Richard Lough in Paris; Writing by Josephine Mason Editing by Catherine Evans and Barbara Lewis)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-411336566", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "13:59:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T13:59:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T13:59:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://business.inquirer.net/467246/eu-slaps-chinese-electric-cars-with-tariffs-of-up-to-38", "title": "EU slaps Chinese electric cars with tariffs of up to 38%", "body": "Brussels, Belgium -- The European Union on Thursday slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 percent on Chinese electric car imports because of \"unfair\" state subsidies, despite Beijing's warnings the move would unleash a trade war.\n\nA European Commission probe launched last year concluded that state subsidies for Chinese EV manufacturers were unfairly undercutting European rivals -- which Brussels wants to shield as they make the transition from thermal to electric power.\n\nThe Chinese Chamber of Commerce to the EU slammed the tariffs, coming on top of current import duties of 10 percent, as \"politically-motivated\" and \"protectionist\", while voicing hope the dispute could yet be resolved through dialogue.\n\nREAD: China warns EU tariffs on EVs would 'harm' Europe's interests\n\nEuropeans themselves are split on the move, with Germany and its homegrown auto champions, who do significant trade with China, fearing it will do more harm than good if it leads to a clampdown on EU exports as Beijing has already threatened.\n\nGerman auto giant Volkswagen slammed the move as \"detrimental\" while the head of BMW said the tariff battle \"leads to a dead end\".\n\nFrance and Italy have pushed for tariffs on Chinese EVs -- whose market share in the EU has skyrocketed -- but Sweden like Germany has expressed reservations, while Hungary is outright opposed.\n\nThe provisional tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU's 27 member states.\n\n\"Our investigation... concluded that the battery electric vehicles produced in China benefit from unfair subsidization, which is causing a threat of economic injury to the EU's own electric car makers,\" the EU's trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said.\n\nREAD: China premier calls to 'oppose decoupling' at economic forum\n\nIn response, the commission imposed provisional duties on major Chinese manufacturers including 17.4 percent for market major BYD, 19.9 percent for Geely and 37.6 percent for SAIC.\n\nOther producers in China that cooperated with the EU will face a tariff of 20.8 percent, while those that did not cooperate would be subject to the maximum 37.6 percent duty.\n\nUS tech billionaire Elon Musk's Tesla -- which manufactures in China -- is the only electric automaker that has asked Brussels for its own duty rate, to be calculated based on evidence it has submitted.\n\n'Intensive' talks with China\n\nThe move comes despite the opening of talks between Chinese and EU trade officials, but Brussels will continue \"to engage intensively with China on a mutually acceptable solution\", trade chief Dombrovskis said.\n\nChina's electric car maker Nio said it still hoped for a resolution with the EU, while fellow EV maker XPeng said it would \"find ways to minimise the impact on consumers\" without changing its international strategy.\n\nEU officials have indicated that, should a negotiated solution emerge, they may not ultimately need to levy the tariffs.\n\nREAD: Chinese firms eye Morocco to cash in on US electric vehicle subsidies\n\nBut Dombrovskis cautioned that \"any negotiated outcome to our investigation must clearly and fully address EU concerns and be in respect of WTO rules.\"\n\nBeijing has already signalled its readiness to retaliate by launching an anti-dumping probe last month into pork imports, threatening Spanish exports, and Chinese media suggest further probes could be in the works.\n\nChinese officials have also railed against EU investigations targeting state subsidies in the green tech sector, including wind turbines and solar panels.\n\nExpected cut to imports\n\nThe United States has already hiked customs duties on Chinese electric cars to 100 percent, while Canada is considering similar action.\n\nBut Brussels faces a delicate balancing act as it seeks to defend Europe's auto industry -- the jewel in its industrial crown -- while both avoiding a damaging showdown with China and meeting its targets for slashing carbon emissions.\n\nThe EU aims for Europeans to switch massively to electric vehicles as it plans to outlaw the sale of new fossil fuel-powered cars from 2035.\n\nChinese-made EVs' market share in the EU climbed from around three percent to more than 20 percent in the past three years, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association.\n\nChinese brands account for around eight percent of that share, it said.\n\nGerman displeasure\n\nGermany's Kiel Institute for the World Economy, alongside Austrian institutes, predicted the provisional higher taxes would reduce vehicle imports from China by 42 percent. They added that electric car prices could rise by an average of 0.3 to 0.9 percent in the EU.\n\nGerman auto manufacturers fear any retaliation could hurt their activities in China, and Germany's Vice Chancellor Robert Habeck visited Beijing last month on an 11th hour mission to avert a damaging trade war.\n\nDuties were \"generally not suitable for strengthening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry in the long term -- we reject them\", Volkswagen said in a statement. The EU refused to comment on the criticism.", "source": {"uri": "business.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inquirer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "agence_france_presse@business.inquirer.net", {"uri": "8209564824", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "12:49:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T12:49:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T12:49:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/renewables/eu-slaps-chinese-electric-cars-with-tariffs-of-up-to-38/articleshow/111491038.cms", "title": "EU slaps Chinese electric cars with tariffs of up to 38%", "body": "The European Union imposed provisional duties of up to 38 per cent on Chinese electric car imports due to alleged unfair state subsidies, sparking concerns of a trade war. The move was criticised by China as \"politically motivated\" and \"protectionist.\" European countries are divided on the issue, with Germany fearing harm to its auto industry. Talks with China continue, with hopes for a negotiated solution to avoid escalating tensions.The European Union on Thursday slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 percent on Chinese electric car imports because of \"unfair\" state subsidies, despite Beijing's warnings the move would unleash a trade war.\n\nA European Commission probe launched last year concluded that state subsidies for Chinese EV manufacturers were unfairly undercutting European rivals -- which Brussels wants to shield as they make the transition from thermal to electric power.\n\nThe Chinese Chamber of Commerce to the EU slammed the tariffs, coming on top of current import duties of 10 percent, as \"politically-motivated\" and \"protectionist\", while voicing hope the dispute could yet be resolved through dialogue.\n\nEuropeans themselves are split on the move, with Germany and its homegrown auto champions, who do significant trade with China, fearing it will do more harm than good if it leads to a clampdown on EU exports as Beijing has already threatened.\n\nGerman auto giant Volkswagen slammed the move as \"detrimental\" while the head of BMW said the tariff battle \"leads to a dead end\".\n\nFrance and Italy have pushed for tariffs on Chinese EVs -- whose market share in the EU has skyrocketed -- but Sweden like Germany has expressed reservations, while Hungary is outright opposed.\n\nThe provisional tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU's 27 member states.\n\n\"Our investigation... concluded that the battery electric vehicles produced in China benefit from unfair subsidisation, which is causing a threat of economic injury to the EU's own electric car makers,\" the EU's trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said.\n\nIn response, the commission imposed provisional duties on major Chinese manufacturers including 17.4 percent for market major BYD, 19.9 percent for Geely and 37.6 percent for SAIC.\n\nOther producers in China that cooperated with the EU will face a tariff of 20.8 percent, while those that did not cooperate would be subject to the maximum 37.6 percent duty.\n\nUS tech billionaire Elon Musk's Tesla -- which manufactures in China -- is the only electric automaker that has asked Brussels for its own duty rate, to be calculated based on evidence it has submitted.\n\nThe move comes despite the opening of talks between Chinese and EU trade officials, but Brussels will continue \"to engage intensively with China on a mutually acceptable solution\", trade chief Dombrovskis said.\n\nChina's electric car maker Nio said it still hoped for a resolution with the EU, while fellow EV maker XPeng said it would \"find ways to minimise the impact on consumers\" without changing its international strategy.\n\nEU officials have indicated that, should a negotiated solution emerge, they may not ultimately need to levy the tariffs.\n\nBut Dombrovskis cautioned that \"any negotiated outcome to our investigation must clearly and fully address EU concerns and be in respect of WTO rules.\"\n\nBeijing has already signalled its readiness to retaliate by launching an anti-dumping probe last month into pork imports, threatening Spanish exports, and Chinese media suggest further probes could be in the works.\n\nChinese officials have also railed against EU investigations targeting state subsidies in the green tech sector, including wind turbines and solar panels.\n\nThe United States has already hiked customs duties on Chinese electric cars to 100 percent, while Canada is considering similar action.\n\nBut Brussels faces a delicate balancing act as it seeks to defend Europe's auto industry -- the jewel in its industrial crown -- while both avoiding a damaging showdown with China and meeting its targets for slashing carbon emissions.\n\nThe EU aims for Europeans to switch massively to electric vehicles as it plans to outlaw the sale of new fossil fuel-powered cars from 2035.\n\nChinese-made EVs' market share in the EU climbed from around three percent to more than 20 percent in the past three years, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association.\n\nChinese brands account for around eight percent of that share, it said.\n\nGermany's Kiel Institute for the World Economy, alongside Austrian institutes, predicted the provisional higher taxes would reduce vehicle imports from China by 42 percent. They added that electric car prices could rise by an average of 0.3 to 0.9 percent in the EU.\n\nGerman auto manufacturers fear any retaliation could hurt their activities in China, and Germany's Vice Chancellor Robert Habeck visited Beijing last month on an 11th hour mission to avert a damaging trade war.\n\nDuties were \"generally not suitable for strengthening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry in the long term -- we reject them\", Volkswagen said in a statement. The EU refused to comment on the criticism.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": which Brussels wants to shield as they make the transition from thermal to electric power.\n\nThe Chinese Chamber of Commerce to the EU slammed the tariffs, coming on top of current import duties of 10%, as \"politically motivated\" and \"protectionist,\" while voicing hope the dispute could be resolved through dialogue.\n\nEuropeans themselves are split on the move, with Germany and its homegrown auto champions, who do significant trade with China, fearing it will do more harm than good if it leads to a clampdown on EU exports as Beijing has already threatened.\n\nGerman auto giant Volkswagen slammed the move as \"detrimental,\" while the head of BMW said the tariff battle \"leads to a dead end.\"\n\nFrance and Italy have pushed for tariffs on Chinese EVs - whose market share in the EU has skyrocketed - but Sweden like Germany has expressed reservations, while Hungary is outright opposed.\n\nThe provisional tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU's 27 member states.\n\n\"Our investigation ... concluded that the battery electric vehicles produced in China benefit from unfair subsidization, which is causing a threat of economic injury to the EU's own electric car makers,\" the EU's trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said.\n\nIn response, the commission imposed provisional duties on major Chinese manufacturers, including 17.4% for market major BYD, 19.9% for Geely and 37.6% for SAIC.\n\nOther producers in China that cooperated with the EU will face a tariff of 20.8%, while those that did not cooperate would be subject to the maximum 37.6% duty.\n\nU.S. tech billionaire Elon Musk's Tesla - which is manufactured in China - is the only electric automaker that has asked Brussels for its own duty rate, to be calculated based on evidence it has submitted.\n\nThe move comes despite the opening of talks between Chinese and EU trade officials, but Brussels will continue \"to engage intensively with China on a mutually acceptable solution,\" trade chief Dombrovskis said.\n\nChina's electric car maker Nio said it still hoped for a resolution with the EU, while fellow EV maker XPeng said it would \"find ways to minimize the impact on consumers\" without changing its international strategy.\n\nEU officials have indicated that should a negotiated solution emerge, they may not ultimately need to levy the tariffs.\n\nBut Dombrovskis cautioned that \"any negotiated outcome to our investigation must clearly and fully address EU concerns and be in respect of WTO rules.\"\n\nBeijing has already signaled its readiness to retaliate by launching an anti-dumping probe last month into pork imports, threatening Spanish exports, and Chinese media suggest further probes could be in the works.\n\nChinese officials have also railed against EU investigations targeting state subsidies in the green tech sector, including wind turbines and solar panels.\n\nThe United States has already hiked customs duties on Chinese electric cars to 100%, while Canada is considering similar action.\n\nBut Brussels faces a delicate balancing act as it seeks to defend Europe's auto industry - the jewel in its industrial crown - while both avoiding a damaging showdown with China and meeting its targets for slashing carbon emissions.\n\nThe EU aims for Europeans to switch massively to electric vehicles as it plans to outlaw the sale of new fossil fuel-powered cars from 2035.\n\nChinese-made EVs' market share in the EU climbed from around 3% to more than 20% in the past three years, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association (ACEA).\n\nChinese brands account for around 8% of that share, it said.\n\nGermany's Kiel Institute for the World Economy, alongside Austrian institutes, predicted the provisional higher taxes would reduce vehicle imports from China by 42%. They added that electric car prices could rise by an average of 0.3 to 0.9% in the EU.\n\nGerman auto manufacturers fear any retaliation could hurt their activities in China, and Germany's Vice Chancellor Robert Habeck visited Beijing last month on an 11th-hour mission to avert a damaging trade war.\n\nDuties were \"generally not suitable for strengthening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry in the long term - we reject them,\" Volkswagen said in a statement. {"uri": "8209590426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "13:07:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T13:07:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T13:06:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://punchng.com/eu-slaps-chinese-electric-cars-with-38-tariffs/", "title": "EU slaps Chinese electric cars with 38% tariffs", "body": "The European Union on Thursday slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 percent on Chinese electric car imports because of \"unfair\" state subsidies, despite Beijing's warnings the move would unleash a trade war.\n\nA European Commission probe launched last year concluded that state subsidies for Chinese EV manufacturers were unfairly undercutting European rivals -- which Brussels wants to shield as they make the transition from thermal to electric power.\n\nThe Chinese Chamber of Commerce to the EU slammed the tariffs, coming on top of current import duties of 10 percent, as \"politically motivated\" and \"protectionist\", while voicing hope the dispute could yet be resolved through dialogue.\n\nEuropeans themselves are split on the move, with Germany and its homegrown auto champions, who do significant trade with China, fearing it will do more harm than good if it leads to a clampdown on EU exports as Beijing has already threatened.\n\nGerman auto giant Volkswagen slammed the move as \"detrimental\" while the head of BMW said the tariff battle \"leads to a dead end\".\n\nFrance and Italy have pushed for tariffs on Chinese EVs -- whose market share in the EU has skyrocketed -- but Sweden like Germany has expressed reservations, while Hungary is outright opposed.\n\nThe provisional tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU's 27 member states.\n\n\"Our investigation... concluded that the battery electric vehicles produced in China benefit from unfair subsidisation, which is causing a threat of economic injury to the EU's own electric car makers,\" the EU's trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said.\n\nIn response, the commission imposed provisional duties on major Chinese manufacturers including 17.4 percent for market major BYD, 19.9 percent for Geely, and 37.6 percent for SAIC.\n\nOther producers in China that cooperated with the EU will face a tariff of 20.8 percent, while those that did not cooperate would be subject to the maximum 37.6 percent duty.\n\nUS tech billionaire Elon Musk's Tesla -- which is manufactured in China -- is the only electric automaker that has asked Brussels for its own duty rate, to be calculated based on evidence it has submitted.\n\n- 'Intensive' talks with China -\n\nThe move comes despite the opening of talks between Chinese and EU trade officials, but Brussels will continue \"to engage intensively with China on a mutually acceptable solution\", trade chief Dombrovskis said.\n\nChina's electric car maker Nio said it still hoped for a resolution with the EU, while fellow EV maker XPeng said it would \"find ways to minimise the impact on consumers\" without changing its international strategy.\n\nEU officials have indicated that should a negotiated solution emerge, they may not ultimately need to levy the tariffs.\n\nBut Dombrovskis cautioned that \"any negotiated outcome to our investigation must clearly and fully address EU concerns and be in respect of WTO rules.\"\n\nBeijing has already signalled its readiness to retaliate by launching an anti-dumping probe last month into pork imports, threatening Spanish exports, and Chinese media suggest further probes could be in the works.\n\nChinese officials have also railed against EU investigations targeting state subsidies in the green tech sector, including wind turbines and solar panels.\n\n- Expected cut to imports -\n\nThe United States has already hiked customs duties on Chinese electric cars to 100 percent, while Canada is considering similar action.\n\nBut Brussels faces a delicate balancing act as it seeks to defend Europe's auto industry -- the jewel in its industrial crown -- while both avoiding a damaging showdown with China and meeting its targets for slashing carbon emissions.\n\nThe EU aims for Europeans to switch massively to electric vehicles as it plans to outlaw the sale of new fossil fuel-powered cars from 2035.\n\nChinese-made EVs' market share in the EU climbed from around three percent to more than 20 percent in the past three years, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association.\n\nChinese brands account for around eight percent of that share, it said.\n\n- German displeasure -\n\nGermany's Kiel Institute for the World Economy, alongside Austrian institutes, predicted the provisional higher taxes would reduce vehicle imports from China by 42 percent. They added that electric car prices could rise by an average of 0.3 to 0.9 percent in the EU.\n\nGerman auto manufacturers fear any retaliation could hurt their activities in China, and Germany's Vice Chancellor Robert Habeck visited Beijing last month on an 11th-hour mission to avert a damaging trade war.\n\nDuties were \"generally not suitable for strengthening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry in the long term -- we reject them\", Volkswagen said in a statement. {"uri": "2024-07-411031637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "09:34:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T09:34:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T09:23:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/3005943-eu-imposes-up-to-376-tariffs-on-chinese-electric-vehicles-amid-growing-trade-tensions", "title": "EU Imposes Up to 37.6% Tariffs on Chinese Electric Vehicles Amid Growing Trade Tensions", "body": "The European Union will impose tariffs ranging from 17.4% to 37.6% on Chinese electric vehicle imports starting Friday to curb the influx of subsidized, low-cost EVs. The decision could escalate trade tensions with China, which may respond with retaliatory tariffs. Technical talks are ongoing to resolve the issue.\n\nThe European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6% from Friday on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials said on Thursday, ratcheting up trade tension with Beijing. There is however a four-month window during which the tariffs are only provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4% and 37.6% without backdating are designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen has said is a threatened flood of cheap EVs built state subsidies. The rates are almost exactly the same as those announced by the Commission on June 12. The executive made slight adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests. These could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run. At the end of it, the Commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose \"definite duties\", typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue. \"There is still a four-month window before arbitration, and we hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD will face duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports. Companies deemed by the EU to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla and BMW, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6%. The Commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025. It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took only limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed. The EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October. The Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have only a modest impact on the majority of Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-411245949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "12:36:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T12:36:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T12:33:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/eu-slaps-chinese-electric-cars-tariffs-38-1849217", "title": "EU Slaps Chinese Electric Cars With Tariffs Of Up To 38%", "body": "The European Union on Thursday slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 percent on Chinese electric car imports because of \"unfair\" state subsidies, despite Beijing's warnings the move would unleash a trade war.\n\nA European Commission probe launched last year concluded that state subsidies for Chinese EV manufacturers were unfairly undercutting European rivals -- which Brussels wants to shield as they make the transition from thermal to electric power.\n\nThe Chinese Chamber of Commerce to the EU slammed the tariffs, coming on top of current import duties of 10 percent, as \"politically-motivated\" and \"protectionist\", while voicing hope the dispute could yet be resolved through dialogue.\n\nEuropeans themselves are split on the move, with Germany and its homegrown auto champions, who do significant trade with China, fearing it will do more harm than good if it leads to a clampdown on EU exports as Beijing has already threatened.\n\nGerman auto giant Volkswagen slammed the move as \"detrimental\" while the head of BMW said the tariff battle \"leads to a dead end\".\n\nFrance and Italy have pushed for tariffs on Chinese EVs -- whose market share in the EU has skyrocketed -- but Sweden like Germany has expressed reservations, while Hungary is outright opposed.\n\nThe provisional tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU's 27 member states.\n\n\"Our investigation... concluded that the battery electric vehicles produced in China benefit from unfair subsidisation, which is causing a threat of economic injury to the EU's own electric car makers,\" the EU's trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said.\n\nIn response, the commission imposed provisional duties on major Chinese manufacturers including 17.4 percent for market major BYD, 19.9 percent for Geely and 37.6 percent for SAIC.\n\nOther producers in China that cooperated with the EU will face a tariff of 20.8 percent, while those that did not cooperate would be subject to the maximum 37.6 percent duty.\n\nUS tech billionaire Elon Musk's Tesla -- which manufactures in China -- is the only electric automaker that has asked Brussels for its own duty rate, to be calculated based on evidence it has submitted.\n\nThe move comes despite the opening of talks between Chinese and EU trade officials, but Brussels will continue \"to engage intensively with China on a mutually acceptable solution\", trade chief Dombrovskis said.\n\nChina's electric car maker Nio said it still hoped for a resolution with the EU, while fellow EV maker XPeng said it would \"find ways to minimise the impact on consumers\" without changing its international strategy.\n\nEU officials have indicated that, should a negotiated solution emerge, they may not ultimately need to levy the tariffs.\n\nBut Dombrovskis cautioned that \"any negotiated outcome to our investigation must clearly and fully address EU concerns and be in respect of WTO rules.\"\n\nBeijing has already signalled its readiness to retaliate by launching an anti-dumping probe last month into pork imports, threatening Spanish exports, and Chinese media suggest further probes could be in the works.\n\nChinese officials have also railed against EU investigations targeting state subsidies in the green tech sector, including wind turbines and solar panels.\n\nThe United States has already hiked customs duties on Chinese electric cars to 100 percent, while Canada is considering similar action.\n\nBut Brussels faces a delicate balancing act as it seeks to defend Europe's auto industry -- the jewel in its industrial crown -- while both avoiding a damaging showdown with China and meeting its targets for slashing carbon emissions.\n\nThe EU aims for Europeans to switch massively to electric vehicles as it plans to outlaw the sale of new fossil fuel-powered cars from 2035.\n\nChinese-made EVs' market share in the EU climbed from around three percent to more than 20 percent in the past three years, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association.\n\nChinese brands account for around eight percent of that share, it said.\n\nGermany's Kiel Institute for the World Economy, alongside Austrian institutes, predicted the provisional higher taxes would reduce vehicle imports from China by 42 percent. They added that electric car prices could rise by an average of 0.3 to 0.9 percent in the EU.\n\nGerman auto manufacturers fear any retaliation could hurt their activities in China, and Germany's Vice Chancellor Robert Habeck visited Beijing last month on an 11th hour mission to avert a damaging trade war.\n\nDuties were \"generally not suitable for strengthening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry in the long term -- we reject them\", Volkswagen said in a statement. {"uri": "8209580331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "12:59:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T12:59:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T12:59:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/world/2024/07/501_378070.html", "title": "EU slaps Chinese electric cars with tariffs of up to 38%", "body": "A general view of visitors looking at models from BYD, a Chinese automobile manufacturer, during an event a day ahead of the official opening of the 2023 Munich Auto Show IAA Mobility, in Munich, Germany, September 4, 2023. Reuters-Yonhap\n\nThe European Union on Thursday slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 percent on Chinese electric car imports because of \"unfair\" state subsidies, despite Beijing's warnings the move would unleash a trade war.\n\nA European Commission probe launched last year concluded that state subsidies for Chinese EV manufacturers were unfairly undercutting European rivals -- which Brussels wants to shield as they make the transition from thermal to electric power.\n\nThe Chinese Chamber of Commerce to the EU slammed the tariffs, coming on top of current import duties of 10 percent, as \"politically-motivated\" and \"protectionist\", while voicing hope the dispute could yet be resolved through dialogue.\n\nEuropeans themselves are split on the move, with Germany and its homegrown auto champions, who do significant trade with China, fearing it will do more harm than good if it leads to a clampdown on EU exports as Beijing has already threatened.\n\nGerman auto giant Volkswagen slammed the move as \"detrimental\" while the head of BMW said the tariff battle \"leads to a dead end\".\n\nFrance and Italy have pushed for tariffs on Chinese EVs -- whose market share in the EU has skyrocketed -- but Sweden like Germany has expressed reservations, while Hungary is outright opposed.\n\nThe provisional tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU's 27 member states.\n\n\"Our investigation... concluded that the battery electric vehicles produced in China benefit from unfair subsidisation, which is causing a threat of economic injury to the EU's own electric car makers,\" the EU's trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said.\n\nIn response, the commission imposed provisional duties on major Chinese manufacturers including 17.4 percent for market major BYD, 19.9 percent for Geely and 37.6 percent for SAIC.\n\nOther producers in China that cooperated with the EU will face a tariff of 20.8 percent, while those that did not cooperate would be subject to the maximum 37.6 percent duty.\n\nUS tech billionaire Elon Musk's Tesla -- which manufactures in China -- is the only electric automaker that has asked Brussels for its own duty rate, to be calculated based on evidence it has submitted.\n\nThe move comes despite the opening of talks between Chinese and EU trade officials, but Brussels will continue \"to engage intensively with China on a mutually acceptable solution\", trade chief Dombrovskis said.\n\nChina's electric car maker Nio said it still hoped for a resolution with the EU, while fellow EV maker XPeng said it would \"find ways to minimise the impact on consumers\" without changing its international strategy.\n\nEU officials have indicated that, should a negotiated solution emerge, they may not ultimately need to levy the tariffs.\n\nBut Dombrovskis cautioned that \"any negotiated outcome to our investigation must clearly and fully address EU concerns and be in respect of WTO rules.\"\n\nBeijing has already signalled its readiness to retaliate by launching an anti-dumping probe last month into pork imports, threatening Spanish exports, and Chinese media suggest further probes could be in the works.\n\nChinese officials have also railed against EU investigations targeting state subsidies in the green tech sector, including wind turbines and solar panels.\n\nThe United States has already hiked customs duties on Chinese electric cars to 100 percent, while Canada is considering similar action.\n\nBut Brussels faces a delicate balancing act as it seeks to defend Europe's auto industry -- the jewel in its industrial crown -- while both avoiding a damaging showdown with China and meeting its targets for slashing carbon emissions.\n\nThe EU aims for Europeans to switch massively to electric vehicles as it plans to outlaw the sale of new fossil fuel-powered cars from 2035.\n\nChinese-made EVs' market share in the EU climbed from around three percent to more than 20 percent in the past three years, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association.\n\nChinese brands account for around eight percent of that share, it said.\n\nGermany's Kiel Institute for the World Economy, alongside Austrian institutes, predicted the provisional higher taxes would reduce vehicle imports from China by 42 percent. They added that electric car prices could rise by an average of 0.3 to 0.9 percent in the EU.\n\nGerman auto manufacturers fear any retaliation could hurt their activities in China, and Germany's Vice Chancellor Robert Habeck visited Beijing last month on an 11th hour mission to avert a damaging trade war.\n\nDuties were \"generally not suitable for strengthening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry in the long term -- we reject them\", Volkswagen said in a statement. The EU refused to comment on the criticism. {"uri": "8209723474", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "14:38:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T14:38:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T14:37:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.thecitizen.co.tz/tanzania/news/international/european-union-slaps-chinese-electric-cars-with-tariffs-of-up-to-38-percent-4679354", "title": "European Union slaps Chinese electric cars with tariffs of up to 38 percent", "body": "Brussels. The European Union on Thursday slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 percent on Chinese electric car imports because of \"unfair\" state subsidies, despite Beijing's warnings the move would unleash a trade war.\n\nA European Commission probe launched last year concluded that state subsidies for Chinese EV manufacturers were unfairly undercutting European rivals -- which Brussels wants to shield as they make the transition from thermal to electric power.\n\nThe Chinese Chamber of Commerce to the EU slammed the tariffs, coming on top of current import duties of 10 percent, as \"politically-motivated\" and \"protectionist\", while voicing hope the dispute could yet be resolved through dialogue.\n\nEuropeans themselves are split on the move, with Germany and its homegrown auto champions, who do significant trade with China, fearing it will do more harm than good if it leads to a clampdown on EU exports as Beijing has already threatened.\n\nGerman auto giant Volkswagen slammed the move as \"detrimental\" while the head of BMW said the tariff battle \"leads to a dead end\".\n\nFrance and Italy have pushed for tariffs on Chinese EVs -- whose market share in the EU has skyrocketed -- but Sweden like Germany has expressed reservations, while Hungary is outright opposed.\n\nThe provisional tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU's 27 member states.\n\n\"Our investigation... concluded that the battery electric vehicles produced in China benefit from unfair subsidisation, which is causing a threat of economic injury to the EU's own electric car makers,\" the EU's trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said.\n\nIn response, the commission imposed provisional duties on major Chinese manufacturers including 17.4 percent for market major BYD, 19.9 percent for Geely and 37.6 percent for SAIC.\n\nOther producers in China that cooperated with the EU will face a tariff of 20.8 percent, while those that did not cooperate would be subject to the maximum 37.6 percent duty.\n\nUS tech billionaire Elon Musk's Tesla -- which manufactures in China -- is the only electric automaker that has asked Brussels for its own duty rate, to be calculated based on evidence it has submitted.\n\n'Intensive' talks with China\n\nThe move comes despite the opening of talks between Chinese and EU trade officials, but Brussels will continue \"to engage intensively with China on a mutually acceptable solution\", trade chief Dombrovskis said.\n\nChina's electric car maker Nio said it still hoped for a resolution with the EU, while fellow EV maker XPeng said it would \"find ways to minimise the impact on consumers\" without changing its international strategy.\n\nEU officials have indicated that, should a negotiated solution emerge, they may not ultimately need to levy the tariffs.\n\nBut Dombrovskis cautioned that \"any negotiated outcome to our investigation must clearly and fully address EU concerns and be in respect of WTO rules.\"\n\nBeijing has already signalled its readiness to retaliate by launching an anti-dumping probe last month into pork imports, threatening Spanish exports, and Chinese media suggest further probes could be in the works.\n\nChinese officials have also railed against EU investigations targeting state subsidies in the green tech sector, including wind turbines and solar panels.\n\nExpected cut to imports\n\nThe United States has already hiked customs duties on Chinese electric cars to 100 percent, while Canada is considering similar action.\n\nBut Brussels faces a delicate balancing act as it seeks to defend Europe's auto industry -- the jewel in its industrial crown -- while both avoiding a damaging showdown with China and meeting its targets for slashing carbon emissions.\n\nThe EU aims for Europeans to switch massively to electric vehicles as it plans to outlaw the sale of new fossil fuel-powered cars from 2035.\n\nChinese-made EVs' market share in the EU climbed from around three percent to more than 20 percent in the past three years, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association.\n\nChinese brands account for around eight percent of that share, it said.\n\nGerman displeasure\n\nGermany's Kiel Institute for the World Economy, alongside Austrian institutes, predicted the provisional higher taxes would reduce vehicle imports from China by 42 percent. They added that electric car prices could rise by an average of 0.3 to 0.9 percent in the EU.\n\nGerman auto manufacturers fear any retaliation could hurt their activities in China, and Germany's Vice Chancellor Robert Habeck visited Beijing last month on an 11th hour mission to avert a damaging trade war.\n\nDuties were \"generally not suitable for strengthening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry in the long term -- we reject them\", Volkswagen said in a statement. The EU refused to comment on the criticism.\n\nBrussels. The European Union on Thursday slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 percent on Chinese electric car imports because of \"unfair\" state subsidies, despite Beijing's warnings the move would unleash a trade war.\n\nA European Commission probe launched last year concluded that state subsidies for Chinese EV manufacturers were unfairly undercutting European rivals -- which Brussels wants to shield as they make the transition from thermal to electric power.\n\nThe Chinese Chamber of Commerce to the EU slammed the tariffs, coming on top of current import duties of 10 percent, as \"politically-motivated\" and \"protectionist\", while voicing hope the dispute could yet be resolved through dialogue.\n\nEuropeans themselves are split on the move, with Germany and its homegrown auto champions, who do significant trade with China, fearing it will do more harm than good if it leads to a clampdown on EU exports as Beijing has already threatened.\n\nGerman auto giant Volkswagen slammed the move as \"detrimental\" while the head of BMW said the tariff battle \"leads to a dead end\".\n\nFrance and Italy have pushed for tariffs on Chinese EVs -- whose market share in the EU has skyrocketed -- but Sweden like Germany has expressed reservations, while Hungary is outright opposed.\n\nThe provisional tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU's 27 member states.\n\n\"Our investigation... concluded that the battery electric vehicles produced in China benefit from unfair subsidisation, which is causing a threat of economic injury to the EU's own electric car makers,\" the EU's trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said.\n\nIn response, the commission imposed provisional duties on major Chinese manufacturers including 17.4 percent for market major BYD, 19.9 percent for Geely and 37.6 percent for SAIC.\n\nOther producers in China that cooperated with the EU will face a tariff of 20.8 percent, while those that did not cooperate would be subject to the maximum 37.6 percent duty.\n\nUS tech billionaire Elon Musk's Tesla -- which manufactures in China -- is the only electric automaker that has asked Brussels for its own duty rate, to be calculated based on evidence it has submitted.\n\n'Intensive' talks with China\n\nThe move comes despite the opening of talks between Chinese and EU trade officials, but Brussels will continue \"to engage intensively with China on a mutually acceptable solution\", trade chief Dombrovskis said.\n\nChina's electric car maker Nio said it still hoped for a resolution with the EU, while fellow EV maker XPeng said it would \"find ways to minimise the impact on consumers\" without changing its international strategy.\n\nEU officials have indicated that, should a negotiated solution emerge, they may not ultimately need to levy the tariffs.\n\nBut Dombrovskis cautioned that \"any negotiated outcome to our investigation must clearly and fully address EU concerns and be in respect of WTO rules.\"\n\nBeijing has already signalled its readiness to retaliate by launching an anti-dumping probe last month into pork imports, threatening Spanish exports, and Chinese media suggest further probes could be in the works.\n\nChinese officials have also railed against EU investigations targeting state subsidies in the green tech sector, including wind turbines and solar panels.\n\nExpected cut to imports\n\nThe United States has already hiked customs duties on Chinese electric cars to 100 percent, while Canada is considering similar action.\n\nBut Brussels faces a delicate balancing act as it seeks to defend Europe's auto industry -- the jewel in its industrial crown -- while both avoiding a damaging showdown with China and meeting its targets for slashing carbon emissions.\n\nThe EU aims for Europeans to switch massively to electric vehicles as it plans to outlaw the sale of new fossil fuel-powered cars from 2035.\n\nChinese-made EVs' market share in the EU climbed from around three percent to more than 20 percent in the past three years, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association.\n\nChinese brands account for around eight percent of that share, it said.\n\nGerman displeasure\n\nGermany's Kiel Institute for the World Economy, alongside Austrian institutes, predicted the provisional higher taxes would reduce vehicle imports from China by 42 percent. They added that electric car prices could rise by an average of 0.3 to 0.9 percent in the EU.\n\nGerman auto manufacturers fear any retaliation could hurt their activities in China, and Germany's Vice Chancellor Robert Habeck visited Beijing last month on an 11th hour mission to avert a damaging trade war.\n\nDuties were \"generally not suitable for strengthening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry in the long term -- we reject them\", Volkswagen said in a statement. {"uri": "8209361236", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:37:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:37:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:37:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2024/0704/1458148-eu-imposes-duties-on-china-built-evs/", "title": "EU imposes duties on China-built EVs", "body": "The European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6% from tomorrow on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials said today, ratcheting up trade tension with Beijing.\n\nThere is however a four-month window during which the tariffs are only provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4% and 37.6% - without backdating - are designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen has said is a threatened flood of cheap EVs built state subsidies.\n\nThe rates are almost exactly the same as those announced by the Commission on June 12. The executive made slight adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nThese could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the Commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose \"definite duties\", typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\nChina's commerce ministry said today that both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue.\n\n\"There is still a four-month window before arbitration, and we hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD will face duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said today. These are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed by the EU to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla and BMW, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6%.\n\nThe Commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025. It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took only limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed.\n\nThe EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have only a modest impact on the majority of Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.",
