{"uri": "8209638475", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "13:37:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T13:37:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T13:37:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/companies-markets/transport-logistics/eu-slaps-chinese-electric-cars-tariffs-38", "title": "EU slaps Chinese electric cars with tariffs of up to 38%", "body": "The European Union on Thursday (Jul 4) slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 per cent on Chinese electric car imports because of \"unfair\" state subsidies, despite Beijing's warnings the move would unleash a trade war.\n\nA European Commission probe launched last year concluded that state subsidies for Chinese EV manufacturers were unfairly undercutting European rivals - which Brussels wants to shield as they make the transition from thermal to electric power.\n\nThe Chinese Chamber of Commerce to the EU slammed the tariffs, coming on top of current import duties of 10 per cent, as \"politically-motivated\" and \"protectionist\", while voicing hope the dispute could yet be resolved through dialogue.\n\nEuropeans themselves are split on the move, with Germany and its homegrown auto champions, who do significant trade with China, fearing it will do more harm than good if it leads to a clampdown on EU exports as Beijing has already threatened.\n\nGerman auto giant Volkswagen slammed the move as \"detrimental\" while the head of BMW said the tariff battle \"leads to a dead end\".\n\nFrance and Italy have pushed for tariffs on Chinese EVs - whose market share in the EU has skyrocketed - but Sweden like Germany has expressed reservations, while Hungary is outright opposed.\n\nThe provisional tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU's 27 member states.\n\n\"Our investigation... concluded that the battery electric vehicles produced in China benefit from unfair subsidisation, which is causing a threat of economic injury to the EU's own electric car makers,\" the EU's trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said.\n\nIn response, the commission imposed provisional duties on major Chinese manufacturers including 17.4 per cent for market major BYD, 19.9 per cent for Geely and 37.6 per cent for SAIC.\n\nOther producers in China that cooperated with the EU will face a tariff of 20.8 per cent, while those that did not cooperate would be subject to the maximum 37.6 per cent duty.\n\nUS tech billionaire Elon Musk's Tesla - which manufactures in China - is the only electric automaker that has asked Brussels for its own duty rate, to be calculated based on evidence it has submitted.\n\nThe move comes despite the opening of talks between Chinese and EU trade officials, but Brussels will continue \"to engage intensively with China on a mutually acceptable solution\", trade chief Dombrovskis said.\n\nChina's electric car maker Nio said it still hoped for a resolution with the EU, while fellow EV maker XPeng said it would \"find ways to minimise the impact on consumers\" without changing its international strategy.\n\nEU officials have indicated that, should a negotiated solution emerge, they may not ultimately need to levy the tariffs.\n\nBut Dombrovskis cautioned that \"any negotiated outcome to our investigation must clearly and fully address EU concerns and be in respect of WTO rules.\"\n\nBeijing has already signalled its readiness to retaliate by launching an anti-dumping probe last month into pork imports, threatening Spanish exports, and Chinese media suggest further probes could be in the works.\n\nChinese officials have also railed against EU investigations targeting state subsidies in the green tech sector, including wind turbines and solar panels.\n\nThe United States has already hiked customs duties on Chinese electric cars to 100 per cent, while Canada is considering similar action.\n\nBut Brussels faces a delicate balancing act as it seeks to defend Europe's auto industry - the jewel in its industrial crown - while both avoiding a damaging showdown with China and meeting its targets for slashing carbon emissions.\n\nThe EU aims for Europeans to switch massively to electric vehicles as it plans to outlaw the sale of new fossil fuel-powered cars from 2035.\n\nChinese-made EVs' market share in the EU climbed from around three per cent to more than 20 per cent in the past three years, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association.\n\nChinese brands account for around eight per cent of that share, it said.\n\nGermany's Kiel Institute for the World Economy, alongside Austrian institutes, predicted the provisional higher taxes would reduce vehicle imports from China by 42 per cent. They added that electric car prices could rise by an average of 0.3 to 0.9 per cent in the EU.\n\nGerman auto manufacturers fear any retaliation could hurt their activities in China, and Germany's Vice Chancellor Robert Habeck visited Beijing last month on an 11th hour mission to avert a damaging trade war.\n\nDuties were \"generally not suitable for strengthening the competitiveness of the European automotive industry in the long term - we reject them\", Volkswagen said in a statement. The EU refused to comment on the criticism. {"uri": "8209763914", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "15:05:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T15:05:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T15:05:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.atalayar.com/en/articulo/economy-and-business/eu-adopts-additional-tariffs-of-up-to-38-on-chinese-electric-vehicles/20240704170000202432.html", "title": "EU adopts additional tariffs of up to 38% on Chinese electric vehicles", "body": "The European Union on Thursday announced the provisional adoption of additional countervailing duties of up to 38% on Chinese electric vehicle manufacturers, saying they benefit from \"unfair\" subsidies.\n\nThese subsidies represent a \"threat of economic injury to European producers\", the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, said in a statement.\n\nThe new tariffs will apply from 5 July.\n\nThe EU intends to adopt a final measure in November, but until then it will hold talks with China in search of a solution, although the Chinese authorities have already warned that they will apply retaliatory measures.\n\nThe Chinese Chamber of Commerce in the EU (CCCEU) denounced Thursday's decision as a \"protectionist measure\".\n\nThe body, which represents more than 1,000 Chinese companies in the EU, said it was \"deeply disappointed and dissatisfied\" with the decision announced on Thursday.\n\nChinese electric car company NIO, which produces high-end models, said in a note that it hopes the Asian giant and the EU \"reach a solution\" to the trade dispute.\n\nMeanwhile, XPeng told AFP that it \"will not change its strategy of exploring foreign markets\" and that it hopes to find \"ways to minimise the impact on consumers\".\n\nIn its statement, the European Commission pointed out that the adoption of these provisional and additional tariffs is the result of a nine-month investigation.\n\nThat investigation concluded that China's electric car value chain \"benefits from unfair subsidies, which is causing a threat of economic injury to EU producers\".\n\nIt therefore announced the provisional adoption of tariffs of 17.4% for BYD and 19.9% for Geely, as well as customs duties of 37.6% for SAIC.\n\nOther electric car producers in China that cooperated in the investigation are subject to average tariffs of 20.8%, while for non-cooperating companies this amounts to 37.6%.\n\nIn May, the European Commission had already threatened to increase tariffs to 38%, on top of the current import duties of 10%.\n\nThe move comes despite trade talks between China and the EU on 22 June.\n\nAccording to EU Trade Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis, the EU will continue to \"work intensively with China on a mutually acceptable solution\".\n\n\"Any negotiated outcome of our investigation must clearly and fully address the EU's concerns and respect World Trade Organisation rules,\" the official said in a note.\n\nLast month, China opened an investigation into pork imports, threatening Spanish exports.\n\nChinese officials have also criticised investigations targeting state subsidies in the green technology sector, including wind turbines and solar panels.\n\nThe EU is seeking to make electric vehicles more widespread, as the bloc will ban the sale of new cars powered by fossil fuel engines from 2035.\n\nAt the same time, it aims to protect its car industry.\n\nHowever, Germany, an automotive powerhouse and a major trading partner of the Asian giant, fears that the high tariffs will generate retaliatory tariffs that will hit its activities in the Chinese market.\n\nOn Thursday, German car giant Volkswagen rejected the high tariffs announced by the EU as \"harmful\".\n\n\"The negative effects of this decision outweigh the potential benefits for the European automotive industry and in particular for Germany,\" the group said.\n\nElectric vehicles from China account for almost 22% of the European market, up from 3% just three {"uri": "2024-07-411038229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "09:41:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T09:41:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T09:29:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/eu-imposes-duties-china-built-092952871.html", "title": "EU imposes duties on China-built EVs, leaving four months for talks", "body": "BRUSSELS (Reuters) - The European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6% from Friday on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials said on Thursday, ratcheting up trade tension with Beijing.\n\nThere is however a four-month window during which the tariffs are only provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4% and 37.6% without backdating are designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen has said is a threatened flood of cheap EVs built state subsidies.\n\nThe rates are almost exactly the same as those announced by the Commission on June 12. The executive made slight adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nThese could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the Commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose \"definite duties\", typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue.\n\n\"There is still a four-month window before arbitration, and we hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD will face duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed by the EU to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla and BMW, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6%.\n\nThe Commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025. It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took only limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed. The EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have only a modest impact on the majority of Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.\n\n(Reporting by Philip Blenkinsop, Charlotte Van Campenhout; Editing by Catherine Evans and Barbara Lewis)", "source": {"uri": "ca.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "2024-07-411263993", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "12:53:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T12:53:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T12:36:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/eu-brushes-aside-risk-china-123609350.html", "title": "EU brushes aside risk of China trade war over electric vehicle tariffs", "body": "The EU's top trade official, Valdis Dombrovskis, has brushed aside concerns of trade-war retaliation from Beijing against European business, after the European Commission imposed duties on Chinese electric vehicles.\n\nDombrovskis, a European Commission vice-president, told Bloomberg Television that talks with China were ongoing, adding: \"We are not seeing the basis for retaliation as what we are conducting is indeed in line with WTO [World Trade Organization] rules.\"\n\nProvisional tariffs on Chinese EV imports to the bloc ranging from 17.4% to 37.6% will apply from Friday, after the two sides failed to reach an agreement on what the EU executive called \"unfair\" subsidies from Beijing.\n\nThese tariffs - far lower than the 100% tariffs imposed by the US - will come on top of the EU's existing 10% duty on electric vehicles from China.\n\nEurope's biggest carmaker, Volkswagen, reiterated its criticism on Thursday of the European Commission's proposed tariffs on EVs made in China , arguing that they would not strengthen Europe's car industry in the long term.\n\nVolkswagen, which is grappling with falling market share in China, has previously warned of retaliation from Beijing. \"The timing of the EU Commission's decision is detrimental to the current weak demand for [battery electric vehicles] in Germany and Europe,\" the company said on Thursday.\n\nStellantis, owner of brands including Citro\u00ebn, Fiat and Vauxhall, has said it will not take a defensive stance in the battle for electric car sales and preferred to \"fight to stay competitive\".\n\nThe tariffs are the result of an ongoing EU investigation launched last October, which found Chinese producers benefited from subsidies at every stage of production, from the mining of lithium used in batteries, to shipping the vehicles to EU ports, such as Rotterdam and Antwerp.\n\n\"Based on the investigation, the commission has concluded that the BEV [battery electric vehicle] value chain in China benefits from unfair subsidisation, which is causing a threat of economic injury to EU BEV producers,\" the commission said in a statement to accompany a legal decision published on Thursday.\n\nThe European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, told Xi Jinping during the Chinese president's recent visit to Europe that \"imbalances\" caused by state support for Chinese industry - leading to artificially cheap products - threatened jobs in Europe, which was \"a matter of great concern\".\n\nChina, which has said it is looking for a \"mutually acceptable solution\" to the dispute, is investigating French cognac and pork imports over subsidies, raising the prospect of tit-for-tat measures.\n\n\"It is plain for all to see who is escalating trade frictions and instigating a 'trade war',\" the Chinese commerce ministry said last month.\n\nChina has won a 25% share of the EU market for electric-battery powered cars, up from 3% in 2020. EU officials fear that without action a vital European industry that employs 2.5 million people and 10.3 million in the wider supply chain could be seriously hurt, just as the EU saw its solar-panel companies lose out to subsidised Chinese competitors.\n\nRelated: Are electric cars too heavy for roads, bridges and car parks?\n\nFrom Friday, importers of Chinese vehicles into the EU will be required to give bank guarantees to customs officers to pay the duties. Money will only be collected if the commission concludes in the autumn that the car industry would have been harmed without these duties.\n\nA final decision on definitive duties - which would be in force for five years - will only be taken in the autumn, pending a vote by the EU's 27 member states.\n\nUnder the provisional measures, China's BYD, which vies with Tesla for the spot of the world's largest producer of electric vehicles, faces a tariff of 17.4%; Geely will pay 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%.\n\nThe rates - calculated according to total subsides and company turnover - have been modestly adjusted downwards in most cases since the required pre-disclosure of tariffs last month, after technical talks with the companies.\n\nThe tariffs enter into force despite staunch opposition from Germany, Europe's largest exporter to China. The Germany government has called for an \"amicable solution\", but also said \"serious movement is needed on the Chinese side\".\n\nGerman officials do not expect to reverse the measures, which can only be overturned by a weighted majority of 15 EU member states representing 65% of the union's population.", "source": {"uri": "uk.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "8209870332", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "16:25:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T16:25:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T16:24:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/world/europe/2024-07-04-eu-slaps-tariffs-on-chinese-electric-vehicles/", "title": "EU slaps tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles", "body": "The rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run. At the end of it, the European Commission could propose \"definite duties\", typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\n\"Those talks with China are ongoing and indeed should a mutually beneficial solution emerge, we can also find ways not to apply at the end of the day the tariffs,\" Dombrovskis said. \"But it is very clear this solution (would) need to solve that market distortion that we are now having ... and it needs to be market compliant.\"\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue. \"We hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" said spokesperson He Yadong.\n\nChinese EV maker BYD will face duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed by the EU to have co-operated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including Western carmakers Tesla and BMW, which manufacture in China, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not co-operate a rate of 37.6%.\n\nCriticism\n\nEurope's biggest carmaker, Volkswagen, was swift to criticise Thursday's announcement. \"The negative effects of this decision outweigh any benefits for the European and especially the German automotive industry,\" a Volkswagen spokesperson said in a statement.\n\nMotor industry executives have warned against the tariffs, fearful of counter-tariffs or other measures that could affect the competitiveness of their cars in China when they are already struggling to keep up with a growing number of domestic competitors in the EV market. German carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China.\n\nThe European Commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025. It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed.\n\nThe issue will be put to EU members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in the European Commission's case, which is the first trade case of this kind. Though it initiated its investigation without an industry complaint, EU members are wavering over whether to back the additional tariffs, highlighting Brussels' challenge in getting support for the case.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs would have a modest effect on the majority of Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.", "source": {"uri": "businesslive.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": "BusinessLIVE"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-411125551", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:51:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:51:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:30:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://theprint.in/tech/china-built-evs-hit-with-duties-in-biggest-eu-trade-case-yet/2160383/", "title": "China-built EVs hit with duties in biggest EU trade case yet", "body": "The rates, laid out in a 208-page document published on Thursday, are almost exactly the same as those announced by the Commission on June 12. The executive made slight adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nThese could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nEU trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said there is no basis for China to retaliate.\n\n\"Our aim is to ... ensure fair competition and level playing field,\" he said in an interview with Bloomberg.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the Commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose \"definite duties\", typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\n\"Those talks with China are ongoing and indeed should a mutually beneficial solution emerge, we can also find ways not to apply at the end of the day the tariffs,\" Dombrovskis said.\n\n\"But it is very clear this solution (would) need to solve that market distortion that we are currently having ... and it needs to be market compliant.\"\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue.\n\n\"We hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD will face duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed by the EU to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla and BMW, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6%.\n\nCRITICISM\n\nEurope's biggest carmaker Volkswagen was swift to criticise Thursday's announcement.\n\n\"The negative effects of this decision outweigh any benefits for the European and especially the German automotive industry,\" a Volkswagen spokesperson said in a statement.\n\nAuto industry executives have warned against the tariffs, fearful of counter-tariffs or other measures that could affect the competitiveness of their cars in China when they are already struggling to keep up with a growing number of domestic competitors in the EV market.\n\nGerman carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China.\n\nThe Commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025. It says prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\nWAVERING EU SUPPORT\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed. The EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October.\n\nThe issue will be put to EU members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in the Commission's case, which is the first trade case of this kind.\n\nAlthough the Commission initiated its investigation without an industry complaint, members are wavering over whether to back the additional tariffs, highlighting Brussels' challenge in getting support for the case.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have a modest impact on the majority of Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100% tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August.\n\n(Reporting by Philip Blenkinsop, Charlotte Van Campenhout; Additional reporting by Victoria Waldersee in Berlin and Richard Lough in Paris; Writing by Josephine MasonEditing by Catherine Evans and Barbara Lewis)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8209922818", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "17:08:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T17:08:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T17:07:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/eu-tariffs-chinese-evs-happen-160236801.html", "title": "EU tariffs on Chinese EVs will happen", "body": "The European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6% from Friday on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials told Reuters, ratcheting up tensions with Beijing in Brussels' largest trade case yet.\n\nThere was, however, a four month window during which the tariffs are provisional and intensive talks were expected to continue between the two sides as Beijing threatens wide ranging retaliation.\n\nReuters noted the European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4% and 37.6% without backdating were designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen had said was a threatened flood of cheap EVs built with state subsidies.\n\nThe rates, laid out in a 208-page document published on Thursday, were almost the same as those announced by the commission on 12 June. The executive made adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nThese could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nEU trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis reportedly said there was no basis for China to retaliate.\n\n\"Our aim is to ... ensure fair competition and a level playing field,\" he said in an interview with Bloomberg cited by Reuters.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose definitive duties, typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\n\"Those talks with China are ongoing and indeed should a mutually beneficial solution emerge, we can also find ways not to apply at the end of the day the tariffs,\" Dombrovskis said.\n\n\"But it is very clear this solution (would) need to solve that market distortion that we are currently having ... and it needs to be market compliant.\"\n\nChina's commerce ministry told Reuters on Thursday both sides had so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue.\n\n\"We hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, [with] sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD faces duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9% and SAIC 37.6%, the EU said on Thursday.\n\nThese are on top of the EU's standard 10% duty on car imports, Reuters noted.\n\nCompanies deemed to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including Tesla and BMW, would be subject to 20.8% tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6%.\n\nChinese EV makers would have to decide whether to absorb the tariffs or raise their prices to cover the billions of dollars in new costs at European borders, Reuters said.\n\n\"Chinese automakers are desperate to expand their sales outside of China since the domestic price war is taking its toll,\" Tu Le, founder of consultancy Sino Auto Insights, told Reuters.\n\nMG and Nio suggested on Thursday they might raise prices in Europe later this year, Reuters said, noting Tesla said last month said it planned to increase the prices of its Model 3.\n\nThe prospect of duties may spur Chinese automakers to invest in factories in Europe, although labour and manufacturing costs are higher than in China, Reuters suggested.\n\nOn Thursday, Xpeng became the latest EV maker to consider setting up manufacturing in the region to avoid the tariffs.\n\nThe Commission had estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market had risen to 8% from below 1% in 2019 and could reach 15% in 2025, Reuters said. Prices are typically 20% below those of EU-made models.\n\n\"EU tariffs on Chinese EVs will happen\" was originally created and published by Just Auto, a GlobalData owned brand.", "source": {"uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! "https://media.zenfs.com/en/just_auto_187/57e727a528ec6eaa28979b286a56cbcd", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9702114", "eventUri": "eng-9702114", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": {"uri": "2024-07-411209461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "12:05:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T12:05:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T12:01:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.technology.org/2024/07/04/eu-to-impose-substantial-tariffs-on-china-made-evs/", "title": "EU to impose substantial tariffs on China-made EVs", "body": "The European Union is set to implement tariffs of up to 37.6% on imports of Chinese-made electric vehicles (EVs) starting Friday, marking the EU's most significant trade case to date. However, these tariffs will be provisional for a four-month period, during which intensive negotiations are expected between the EU and Beijing, as China threatens wide-ranging retaliatory measures.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties, ranging from 17.4% to 37.6%, aim to prevent an influx of inexpensive EVs produced with state subsidies, a situation Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has described as a potential threat to the EU market. The final duty rates were detailed in a 208-page document released on Thursday, with only minor adjustments made from the initial June 12 announcement after companies pointed out calculation errors.\n\nChina has vowed to take \"all necessary measures\" to protect its interests, potentially including retaliatory tariffs on European exports like cognac and pork. However, EU Trade Chief Valdis Dombrovskis insists that there is no justification for China's retaliation, emphasizing the EU's goal of ensuring fair competition and a level playing field. The anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run, after which the Commission could propose definitive duties, usually lasting for five years, pending a vote by EU member states.\n\nDombrovskis remains open to a negotiated resolution, stating that if a mutually beneficial solution is found, the tariffs may not be applied. However, any solution must address the current market distortions and be compliant with market regulations. China's commerce ministry confirmed that several rounds of technical talks have already taken place, expressing hope for sincere and expedited progress in consultations.\n\nThe announced tariffs will affect major Chinese automakers: BYD faces duties of 17.4%, Geely 19.9%, and SAIC 37.6%. These duties are in addition to the EU's standard 10% import duty on cars. Western carmakers like Tesla and BMW, which cooperated with the investigation, will be subject to 20.8% tariffs, while non-cooperative companies face the maximum rate of 37.6%.\n\nVolkswagen, Europe's largest carmaker, quickly criticized the decision, stating that the negative impacts outweigh any potential benefits for the European and particularly the German automotive industry. Industry executives have expressed concerns about counter-tariffs and other retaliatory measures that could affect their competitiveness in China, where they are already struggling against a growing number of domestic competitors in the EV market. Notably, German carmakers generated a third of their sales in China last year.\n\nThe European Commission estimates that Chinese brands' share of the EU market has increased from below 1% in 2019 to 8%, and could reach 15% by 2025, with prices typically 20% lower than EU-made models. European policymakers are determined to avoid a repeat of the solar panel debacle a decade ago, where limited EU action against Chinese imports led to the collapse of many European manufacturers.", "source": {"uri": "technology.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Technology Org"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": "https://www.technology.org/texorgwp/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/byton-semi-autonomous-car-china-720x443.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9702114", "eventUri": "eng-9702114", "location": {"uri": "2024-07-411458361", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "15:56:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T15:56:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T14:26:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.aol.com/europe-slapping-tariffs-chinese-electric-142609296.html", "title": "Europe is slapping tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles  --  for now. Here's what to know", "body": "Europe is slapping tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles -- for now. Here's what to know\n\nDAVID McHUGH and KEN MORITSUGU\n\nJuly 4, 2024 at 4:26 PM\n\nFRANKFURT, Germany (AP) -- The European Union is imposing sharply higher customs duties on electric vehicles imported from China. EVs are the latest flash point in a broader trade dispute over Chinese government subsidies and Beijing's burgeoning exports of green technology to the 27-nation bloc.\n\nThe higher duties go into effect on Friday, pending a final decision in four month's time.\n\nHere are some basic facts about the EU's planned customs duties:\n\nWhat did the European Union do?\n\nAfter an eight-month investigation, the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, found that companies making electric cars in China benefit from massive government help that means they can undercut rivals in the EU on prices, take a big market share and threaten European jobs.\n\nIt announced the higher duties on June 12 and they go into effect from Friday. The duties are provisional, meaning they will be totaled up but won't need to be paid until they're confirmed by a vote of EU governments before Nov. 2. The EU will only collect the duties if there's a further finding that the European auto industry would have suffered material harm without them.\n\nThat gives the EU and the Chinese government time to negotiate. Talks have been held between Valdis Dombrovskis, the EU commissioner for the economy, and Chinese Trade Minister Wang Wentao, as well as at the level of technical experts.\n\nThe higher duties are not a goal in themselves but \"a means to correct an imbalance,\" commission spokesman Eric Mamer said Thursday. \"We certainly hope we can come to a solution which would allow us not to have to move forward on this path.\"\n\nThe rates, if applied, would be: 17.4% on cars from BYD, 19.9% on those from Geely and 37.6% for vehicles exported by China's state-owned SAIC. Geely has brands including Polestar and Sweden's Volvo, while SAIC owns Britain's MG, one of Europe's bestselling EV brands. Other EV manufacturers in China including Western companies such as Volkswagen, BMW and Tesla would be subject to duties of at least 20.8%. The commission mentioned that Tesla might get an \"individually calculated\" rate if duties are definitively imposed.\n\nUnder EU rules it's possible -- though at present it seems unlikely -- that the higher duties could be blocked ahead of the Nov. 2 effective date by vote of what the EU calls a \"qualified majority\" of countries. That means at least 15 of the 27 EU member governments representing at least 65% of the bloc's population.\n\nWhy did the commission take action?\n\nChinese-built electric cars jumped from 3.9% of the EV market in 2020 to 25% by September 2023, the commission said, in part by unfairly undercutting EU industry prices.\n\nThe commission says companies in China accomplished that with the help of subsidies all along the chain of production, from cheap land for factories from local governments to below-market supplies of lithium and batteries from state-owned enterprises to tax breaks and below-interest financing from state-controlled banks.\n\nThe rapid growth in market share has sparked fears that Chinese cars will eventually threaten the EU's ability to produce its own green technology needed to combat climate change, as well as the jobs of 2.5 million workers at risk in the auto industry and 10.3 million more people whose jobs depend indirectly on EV production.\n\nSubsidized solar panels from China have wiped out European producers -- an experience that European governments don't want to see repeated with their auto industry.\n\nUnusually, the commission acted on its own, without a complaint from the European auto industry. Industry leaders and Germany, home to BMW, Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz, have been skeptics about the subsidy investigation. That's because many of the cars that will be hit with tariffs are made by European companies, and because China could retaliate against the auto industry or in other areas.\n\nHow do the EU tariffs compare to ones announced by the U.S.?\n\nThe Biden administration is raising tariffs on Chinese EVs to 100% from the current 25%. At that level, the U.S. tariffs block virtually all Chinese EV imports.\n\nThat's not what Europe is trying to do.\n\nEU officials want affordable electric cars from abroad to achieve their goals of cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030 -- but without the subsidies EU leaders see as unfair competition\n\nThe planned tariffs are aimed at leveling the playing field by approximating the size of the excess or unfair subsidies available to Chinese carmakers.\n\nEuropean countries subsidize electric cars, too. The question in trade disputes is whether subsidies are fair and available to all carmakers or distort the market in favor of one side.\n\nJust how cheap are Chinese EVs?\n\nChinese carmakers have learned to make electric vehicles cheaply amid ferocious price competition at home in the world's largest car market.\n\nBYD's Seal U Comfort model sells for the equivalent of 21,769 euros ($23,370) in China but 41,990 euros ($45,078) in Europe, according to Rhodium Group figures. The base model of BYD's compact Seagull, due to arrive in Europe next year, sells for the equivalent of around $10,000 in China.\n\nWhat does this mean for European drivers and carmakers?\n\nIt's not clear what impact the duties will have on car prices. Chinese carmakers are able to make some cars so cheaply that they could absorb the duties in the form of lower profits instead of raising their prices.\n\nWhile consumers might benefit from cheaper Chinese cars in the short term, allowing unfair practices could eventually mean less competition and higher prices in the long term, the commission argues.\n\nCurrently, Chinese carmakers often sell their vehicles in Europe at much higher prices than the same cars fetch in China, meaning they are favoring profits over market share, even given their recent market gains. Five of BYD's six models would still earn a profit in Europe even at a 30% tariff, according to Rhodium Group calculations.\n\nThe fear is Europe is that Chinese competitors will turn to lowering their prices closer to the ones they are charging in China. and gain an even bigger chunk of the market.\n\nHow is China likely to react?\n\nBeijing was sharply critical of the higher duties when they were announced, calling them \"a naked act of protectionism.\"\n\nOn Thursday, He Yadong, a spokesperson for the Chinese Commerce Ministry, said that the two sides had held several rounds of technical consultations and noted that a final EU ruling won't be made for four months.\n\n\"It is hoped that the European side and the Chinese side will move in the same direction, show sincerity, expedite the consultation process and reach a mutually acceptable solution as soon as possible on the basis of facts and rules,\" he said at a weekly media briefing in Beijing.\n\nHe also said that China hopes the EU will seriously listen to the voices of the European automakers and governments that have come out against the tariffs and avoid anti-subsidy measures that would harm cooperation between the Chinese and European auto industries.\n\nIt's not clear what agreement might look like. One move could be to agree on minimum prices for Chinese cars.\n\nChina could retaliate against European products such as pork or brandy imports, or against European luxury car imports.\n\nOver the longer term, Chinese carmakers could avoid tariffs by making cars in Europe. BYD is building a plant in Hungary, while Chery has a joint venture to build cars in Spain's Catalonia region.\n\n___\n\nMoritsugu reported from Beijing.", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8207216221", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "06:35:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T06:35:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T06:34:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/renewables/eu-governments-waver-over-chinese-ev-tariffs-as-trade-spat-escalates/articleshow/111450782.cms", "title": "EU governments waver over Chinese EV tariffs as trade spat escalates", "body": "EU countries debate supporting tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles in Brussels amid concerns over Beijing's possible retaliation affecting EU exports like cognac and pork.EU countries are wavering over whether to back additional tariffs on Chinese-built electric vehicles, highlighting Brussels' challenge in building support for its largest trade case yet as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nGermany, whose carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China, wants to stop the tariffs, according to a government source, while France has been among the firmest backers.\n\nBut a majority of countries are still weighing the pros and cons of the escalating trade spat, according to an informal poll by Reuters of EU governments.\n\nThe issue will be put to members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in a landmark case for the Commission. The EU initiated the probe without an industry complaint, the first such trade case of this kind.\n\nThe bloc is set to confirm on Thursday provisional duties of up to 37.6% on Chinese brands such as BYD, Geely and SAIC, as well as on China-made models of Tesla, BMW and other western automakers.\n\nEU members will also vote in October if the Commission proposes multi-year tariffs at the end of its investigation. These would be blocked if a \"qualified majority\" if at least 15 countries representing 65% of the EU population votes against them.\n\nFrance, Italy and Spain, with 40% of the EU population, have indicated they would back tariffs.\n\n\"Europe must defend itself if our companies are harmed and do not compete on equal terms,\" Spain's economy ministry said.\n\nHowever, the Czech Republic, Greece, Ireland and Poland were still debating the issue, official and government sources said, while Belgium has a caretaker government and the Dutch only got a government this week.\n\nNEGATIVE EFFECTS\n\nGermany has stressed the need for a negotiated solution with Beijing. Its automakers have said tariffs are the wrong approach, with the negative effects outweighing any benefits.\n\nIncreasing the cost of EVs for consumers undermines the EU's goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050, opponents say. Tesla has said it will hike prices.\n\nBeijing's retaliation could bring extra tariffs on EU exports of cognac, pork or luxury cars.\n\nThe Commission says duties are needed to counter cheap loans, land and raw materials and other subsidies and the goal is a level playing field, not shutting Chinese car makers out, as the United States' planned 100% tariff is likely to do.\n\nTariffs could also give the EU leverage in negotiations with Beijing and push producers to make cars in the EU.\n\nHosuk Lee-Makiyama, director of thinktank the European Centre for International Political Economy, said clear majorities either way could embolden tariff opponents or supporters. He added final positions at the end of the investigation will depend on what Beijing offers in negotiations.\n\n\"If we go to a vote then, it means negotiations have failed,\" he said.\n\nThe EV investigation could just be the start for the EU as it toughens its stance on Beijing, as its green and tech companies trail global rivals, interviews with half a dozen trade experts show.\n\nThey point to a 712-page updated report on Chinese state interference and subsidies released in April as the strongest sign yet that Brussels means business.\n\nThe document is by far the most extensive undertaken by the Commission, showing it has learned a lesson from an investigation into Chinese solar panels a decade ago, when it did not impose tariffs and the EU's own industry collapsed.\n\nIt offers proof to back its assertions that China does not play by the same rules and includes research into a wider range of industries, beyond traditional ones such as steel, including semiconductors, telecom equipment and renewable energy.\n\nThat leaves the door open to future cases.\n\n\"This is a report to set the scene and show how and why Europe is changing its policies,\" said Alicia Garcia Herrero, a senior fellow at Brussels-based economic thinktank Bruegel. \"To be frank, it's also a message especially for the German chancellery.\"", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", {"uri": "8207173778", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "06:05:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T06:05:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T06:03:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/headlines/3004472-eus-ev-tariff-dilemma-balancing-trade-and-sustainability", "title": "EU's EV Tariff Dilemma: Balancing Trade and Sustainability | Headlines", "body": "EU countries are debating additional tariffs on Chinese-built electric vehicles amid concerns of economic retaliation from Beijing. Germany opposes the tariffs due to its automotive trade with China, while France supports them. The EU's decision will significantly impact trade relationships and its goal of carbon neutrality.\n\nEU countries are wavering over whether to back additional tariffs on Chinese-built electric vehicles, highlighting Brussels' challenge in building support for its largest trade case yet as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nGermany, whose carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China, wants to stop the tariffs, according to a government source, while France has been among the firmest backers. But a majority of countries are still weighing the pros and cons of the escalating trade spat, according to an informal poll by Reuters of EU governments.\n\nThe issue will be put to members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in a landmark case for the Commission. The EU initiated the probe without an industry complaint, the first such trade case of this kind. The bloc is set to confirm on Thursday provisional duties of up to 37.6% on Chinese brands such as BYD, Geely and SAIC, as well as on China-made models of Tesla, BMW and other western automakers.\n\nEU members will also vote in October if the Commission proposes multi-year tariffs at the end of its investigation. These would be blocked if a \"qualified majority\" if at least 15 countries representing 65% of the EU population votes against them. France, Italy and Spain, with 40% of the EU population, have indicated they would back tariffs.\n\n\"Europe must defend itself if our companies are harmed and do not compete on equal terms,\" Spain's economy ministry said. However, the Czech Republic, Greece, Ireland and Poland were still debating the issue, official and government sources said, while Belgium has a caretaker government and the Dutch only got a government this week.\n\nNEGATIVE EFFECTS Germany has stressed the need for a negotiated solution with Beijing. Its automakers have said tariffs are the wrong approach, with the negative effects outweighing any benefits.\n\nIncreasing the cost of EVs for consumers undermines the EU's goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050, opponents say. Tesla has said it will hike prices. Beijing's retaliation could bring extra tariffs on EU exports of cognac, pork or luxury cars.\n\nThe Commission says duties are needed to counter cheap loans, land and raw materials and other subsidies and the goal is a level playing field, not shutting Chinese car makers out, as the United States' planned 100% tariff is likely to do. Tariffs could also give the EU leverage in negotiations with Beijing and push producers to make cars in the EU.\n\nHosuk Lee-Makiyama, director of thinktank the European Centre for International Political Economy, said clear majorities either way could embolden tariff opponents or supporters. He added final positions at the end of the investigation will depend on what Beijing offers in negotiations. \"If we go to a vote then, it means negotiations have failed,\" he said.\n\nThe EV investigation could just be the start for the EU as it toughens its stance on Beijing, as its green and tech companies trail global rivals, interviews with half a dozen trade experts show. They point to a 712-page updated report on Chinese state interference and subsidies released in April as the strongest sign yet that Brussels means business.\n\nThe document is by far the most extensive undertaken by the Commission, showing it has learned a lesson from an investigation into Chinese solar panels a decade ago, when it did not impose tariffs and the EU's own industry collapsed. It offers proof to back its assertions that China does not play by the same rules and includes research into a wider range of industries, beyond traditional ones such as steel, including semiconductors, telecom equipment and renewable energy.\n\nThat leaves the door open to future cases. \"This is a report to set the scene and show how and why Europe is changing its policies,\" said Alicia Garcia Herrero, a senior fellow at Brussels-based economic thinktank Bruegel. \"To be frank, it's also a message especially for the German chancellery.\"\n\n(This story has not been edited by {"uri": "8208596960", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "23:34:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T23:34:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T23:32:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://kuwaittimes.com/article/16256/business/eu-countries-wavering-on-china-ev-tariffs/", "title": "EU countries wavering on China EV tariffs", "body": "BRUSSELS/LONDON: EU countries are wavering over whether to back additional tariffs on Chinese-built electric vehicles, highlighting Brussels' challenge in building support for its largest trade case yet as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation. Germany, whose carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China, wants to stop the tariffs, according to a government source, while France has been among the firmest backers. But a majority of countries are still weighing the pros and cons of the escalating trade spat, according to an informal poll by Reuters of EU governments.\n\nThe issue will be put to members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in a landmark case for the Commission. The EU initiated the probe without an industry complaint, the first such trade case of this kind. The bloc is set to confirm on Thursday provisional duties of up to 37.6 percent on Chinese brands such as BYD and SAIC, as well as on China-made models of Tesla and other western automakers. Carmakers are bracing for billions of dollars in new costs as a result, which analysts say could slow their European expansion. EU members will also vote in October if the Commission proposes multi-year tariffs at the end of its investigation. These would be blocked if a \"qualified majority\" of at least 15 countries representing 65 percent of the EU population votes against them.\n\nFrance, Italy and Spain, with 40 percent of the EU population, have indicated they would back tariffs.\n\n\"Europe must defend itself if our companies are harmed and do not compete on equal terms,\" Spain's economy ministry said. However, the Czech Republic, Greece, Ireland and Poland were still debating the issue, official and government sources said, while Belgium has a caretaker government and the Dutch only got a government this week. Germany has stressed the need for a negotiated solution with Beijing. Its automakers have said tariffs are the wrong approach, with the negative effects outweighing any benefits. In a last-ditch effort to influence negotiation, its auto association on Wednesday urged Brussels to drop the tariffs.\n\nIncreasing the cost of EVs for consumers undermines the EU's goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050, opponents say. Tesla has said it will hike prices. Beijing's retaliation could bring extra tariffs on EU exports of cognac, pork or luxury cars. The Commission says duties are needed to counter cheap loans, land and raw materials and other subsidies and the goal is a level playing field, not shutting Chinese car makers out, as the United States' planned 100 percent tariff is likely to do.\n\nTariffs could also give the EU leverage in negotiations with Beijing and push producers to make cars in the EU. Hosuk Lee-Makiyama, director of think-tank the European Centre for International Political Economy, said clear majorities either way could embolden tariff opponents or supporters. He added final positions at the end of the investigation will depend on what Beijing offers in negotiations.\n\n\"If we go to a vote then, it means negotiations have failed,\" he said. The EV investigation could just be the start for the EU as it toughens its stance on Beijing, as its green and tech companies trail global rivals, interviews with half a dozen trade experts show.\n\nThey point to a 712-page updated report on Chinese state interference and subsidies released in April as the strongest sign yet that Brussels means business. The document is by far the most extensive undertaken by the Commission, showing it has learned a lesson from an investigation into Chinese solar panels a decade ago, when it did not impose tariffs and the EU's own industry collapsed.\n\nIt offers evidence to back its assertions that China does not play by the same rules and includes research into a wider range of industries, beyond traditional ones such as steel, including semiconductors, telecom equipment and renewable energy. That leaves the door open to future cases. \"This is a report to set the scene and show how and why Europe is changing its policies,\" said Alicia Garcia Herrero, a senior fellow at Brussels-based [China Daily via Reuters]\n\nEU countries are wavering over whether to back additional tariffs on Chinese-built electric vehicles, highlighting Brussels' challenge in building support for its largest trade case yet as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nGermany, whose carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China, wants to stop the tariffs, according to a government source, while France has been among the firmest backers.\n\nBut a majority of countries are still weighing the pros and cons of the escalating trade spat, according to an informal poll by Reuters of EU governments.\n\nThe issue will be put to members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in a landmark case for the Commission. The EU initiated the probe without an industry complaint, the first such trade case of this kind.\n\nThe bloc is set to confirm on Thursday provisional duties of up to 37.6% on Chinese brands such as BYD, Geely and SAIC, as well as on China-made models of Tesla, BMW, and other western automakers.\n\nCarmakers are bracing for billions of dollars in new costs as a result, which analysts say could slow their European expansion.\n\nEU members will also vote in October if the Commission proposes multi-year tariffs at the end of its investigation. These would be blocked if a \"qualified majority\" of at least 15 countries representing 65% of the EU population votes against them.\n\nFrance, Italy and Spain, with 40% of the EU population, have indicated they would back tariffs.\n\n\"Europe must defend itself if our companies are harmed and do not compete on equal terms,\" Spain's economy ministry said.\n\nHowever, the Czech Republic, Greece, Ireland and Poland were still debating the issue, official and government sources said, while Belgium has a caretaker government and the Dutch only got a government this week.\n\nNegative effects\n\nGermany has stressed the need for a negotiated solution with Beijing. Its automakers have said tariffs are the wrong approach, with the negative effects outweighing any benefits.\n\nIn a last-ditch effort to influence negotiation, its auto association on Wednesday urged Brussels to drop the tariffs.\n\nIncreasing the cost of EVs for consumers undermines the EU's goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050, opponents say. Tesla has said it will hike prices.\n\nBeijing's retaliation could bring extra tariffs on EU exports of cognac, pork or luxury cars.\n\nThe Commission says duties are needed to counter cheap loans, land and raw materials and other subsidies and the goal is a level playing field, not shutting Chinese car makers out, as the United States' planned 100% tariff is likely to do.\n\nTariffs could also give the EU leverage in negotiations with Beijing and push producers to make cars in the EU.\n\nHosuk Lee-Makiyama, director of thinktank the European Centre for International Political Economy, said clear majorities either way could embolden tariff opponents or supporters. He added final positions at the end of the investigation will depend on what Beijing offers in negotiations.\n\n\"If we go to a vote then, it means negotiations have failed,\" he said.\n\nThe EV investigation could just be the start for the EU as it toughens its stance on Beijing, as its green and tech companies trail global rivals, interviews with half a dozen trade experts show.\n\nThey point to a 712-page updated report on Chinese state interference and subsidies released in April as the strongest sign yet that Brussels means business.\n\nThe document is by far the most extensive undertaken by the Commission, showing it has learned a lesson from an investigation into Chinese solar panels a decade ago, when it did not impose tariffs and the EU's own industry collapsed.\n\nIt offers evidence to back its assertions that China does not play by the same rules and includes research into a wider range of industries, beyond traditional ones such as steel, including semiconductors, telecom equipment and renewable energy.\n\nThat leaves the door open to future cases.\n\n\"This is a report to set the scene and show how and why Europe is changing its policies,\" said Alicia Garcia Herrero, a senior fellow at Brussels-based economic thinktank Bruegel. \"To be frank, it's also a message especially for the German chancellery.\"\n\n[Reuters]\n\nEU China Trade Subscribe to our Newsletters\n\nEnter your information below to receive our weekly newsletters with the latest insights, opinion pieces and current events straight to your inbox.\n\nSIGN UP NOW Kathimerini may send occasional special offers and promotions. {"uri": "8209855897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "16:14:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T16:14:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T16:13:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.omanobserver.om/article/1155895/business/economy/eu-tariffs-on-china-evs-four-month-talk-window", "title": "EU tariffs on China EVs, four-month talk window", "body": "BRUSSELS: The European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6 per cent from Friday on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials said on Thursday, ratcheting up trade tension with Beijing.\n\nThere is however a four-month window during which the tariffs are only provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4 per cent and 37.6 per cent without backdating are designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen has said is a threatened flood of cheap EVs built state subsidies.\n\nThe rates are almost exactly the same as those announced by the Commission on June 12. The executive made slight adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nThese could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the Commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose \"definite duties\", typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue.\n\n\"There is still a four-month window before arbitration, and we hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD will face duties of 17.4 per cent, Geely 19.9 per cent and SAIC 37.6 per cent, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10 per cent duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed by the EU to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla and BMW, will be subject to 20.8 per cent tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6 per cent. The Commission has estimated Chinese brands' share of the EU market has risen to 8 per cent from below 1 per cent in 2019 and could reach 15 per cent in 2025. It says prices are typically 20 per cent below those of EU-made models.\n\nEuropean policymakers are keen to avoid a repeat of what happened with solar panels a decade ago, when the EU took only limited action to curb Chinese imports and many European manufacturers collapsed. The EU launched its anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs last October.\n\nThe Chinese Passenger Car Association has said the tariffs will have only a modest impact on the majority of Chinese firms.\n\nThe rates are far lower than the 100 per cent tariff Washington plans to apply to Chinese EV imports from August. -- Reuters", "source": {"uri": "omanobserver.om", "dataType": "news", 5, "label": {"eng": "China"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "China"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Beijing"}, {"uri": "8209311024", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:08:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:08:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:07:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/eu-hits-chinese-electric-cars-100208138.html", "title": "EU hits Chinese electric cars with steep tariffs", "body": "The European Union has raised tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles, as Brussels takes action to protect the bloc's motor industry.\n\nThe new tariffs on individual manufactures range from 17.4% to 37.6%, which is on top of a 10% duty that was already in place for all electric cars imported from China.\n\nThis could raise the price of EVs across the EU, making them less affordable for European consumers.\n\nThe move is also a major blow for Beijing, which is already in a trade war with Washington. The EU is the largest overseas market for China's EV industry and the country is counting on high-tech products to help revive its flagging economy.\n\nEU officials say this rise in imports was boosted by \"unfair subsidisation\", which allowed China-made EVs to be sold at much lower prices than ones produced in the bloc.\n\nChina has denied this repeated allegation from the US and the EU: Beijing is subsidising excess production to flood western markets with cheap imports.\n\nThe new charges come into effect on Friday but are currently provisional while the investigation into Chinese state support for the country's EV makers continues.\n\nSo who are the potential winners and losers in this trade dispute?\n\nIt is not just Chinese brands that are affected by the move. Western firms that make cars in China have also come under scrutiny by Brussels.\n\nBy imposing tariffs, Brussels says it is attempting to correct what it sees as a distorted market. The EU's decision may seem tame compared to a recent US move to raise its total tariffs to 100%, but it could be far more consequential. Chinese EVs are a relatively rare sight on US roads but much more common in the EU.\n\nThe number of EVs sold by Chinese brands across the EU rose from just 0.4% of the total EV market in 2019 to almost 8% last year, according to figures from the influential Brussels-based green group Transport and Environment (T&E).\n\nPatryk Krupcala, an architect from Poland, who expects to take delivery of a brand new China-made MG4 in two weeks told the BBC: \"I have chosen an MG4 because it is quite cheap. It is a really fast car and it's a rear-wheel drive like my previous car which was BMW E46.\"\n\nT&E projects firms like BYD and Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation (SAIC), the Chinese owner of the formerly British brand MG, could reach a market share of 20% by 2027.\n\nBut not all Chinese-made EVs will be hit equally by the new tariffs.\n\nThey were calculated based on estimates of how much state aid each firm received, while companies that cooperated with the probe saw the duties they were hit with cut. Based on these criteria, the European Commission has set individual duties on three Chinese EV brands - SAIC, BYD and Geely.\n\nSAIC has been hit with the highest new tariff of 37.6%. State-owned SAIC is the Chinese partner of Volkswagen and General Motors. It also owns MG, which produces one of the top-selling EVs in Europe, the MG4.\n\n\"The price for not cooperating is a severe blow to SAIC, which gets 15.4% of its global revenues from EV sales in Europe,\" says Rhodium Group, an independent research firm.\n\nFor Mr Krupcala, who bought his MG4 before the tariffs hit, the EU's move does not matter much: \"I don't really care about the tariffs. I have a nice car with a seven-year warranty.\"\n\nFor China's largest EV maker, BYD, it is a different story, as it faces an extra duty of 17.4% on the vehicles it ships from China to the EU.\n\nThat is the lowest increase and one that, according to research by Dutch bank ING will \"give the automaker an advantage in the European market\".\n\nLu\u00eds Filipe Costa, an insurance industry executive from Portugal, who has just bought a BYD Seal, says price was one of the deciding factors when he chose his new car.\n\nBut, he added that even if the European Commission's new tariffs had already been in place he would still have gone with BYD because \"other brands would also be affected\".\n\nGeely, which owns Sweden's Volvo, will see an additional tariff of 19.9%.\n\nAccording to Spanish bank BBVA, the company will \"still export to the EU profitably\" but \"its profits will be significantly reduced.\"\n\nOther firms, including European car makers operating factories in China or through joint ventures, will also have to pay more to bring electric cars into the EU.\n\nThose deemed to have cooperated with the probe will face an extra duty of 20.8%, while those EU investigators see as non-cooperative will pay the higher tariff of 37.6%.\n\nUS-based Tesla, which is the biggest exporter of electric vehicles from China to Europe, has asked for an individually calculated rate which EU officials have said will be determined at the end of the investigation.\n\nStill, the firm has posted a notice on some of its European websites, that prices for its Shanghai-made Model 3 could increase due to the new tariffs.\n\nLast year, businessman Lars Koopmann, who lives in the motor industry powerhouse that is Germany, bought a China-made Tesla Model Y.\n\nMr Koopmann says he particularly enjoyed the car's high-tech features, such as the large touch screen.\n\n\"Price was also a big factor that set it apart from premium German brands,\" Mr Koopmann says.\n\n\"If the tariffs had been in place, they would have always affected my decision.\"\n\nWhile some China-based exporters will be better off than others, it is clear from the European Commission's plans that all of them will be facing higher costs when shipping to Europe.\n\nThe hardest hit \"will be SAIC brands like MG... as well as joint ventures between foreign and Chinese firms in China, which often have narrower profit margins on the cars they export to Europe,\" Rhodium says.\n\n\"The biggest beneficiaries of the duties are European-based producers with limited China exposure, such as Renault.\"\n\nIn other words, the duties are likely to do as the EU hopes they would - cut the number of Chinese-made EVs coming into the region, easing pressure on local manufacturers.\n\nThere is also another result of the move - some big Chinese EV firms are planning to build production capacity in the EU, which could help shield them from the new duties.\n\nWork on BYD's first European factory is well under way in Hungary and production is expected to begin there by the end of next year.\n\nChinese car maker, Chery, has recently signed a joint-venture deal with a Spanish firm that will see the two companies making EVs and other types of cars in Barcelona.\n\nAnd, SAIC is looking to secure a site for its first factory in Europe.\n\n\"It's a well architected plan to encourage companies to shift their investments to the EU, instead of relying on exporting from China,\" said Bill Russo, from Shanghai-based consulting group Automobility.\n\n\"The fact that some companies are taxed higher than others is a signal that they will make the penalty higher or lower based on the degree the company is committed to investing in the EU.\"\n\nThe Chinese government placed its bet on EVs early on.\n\nAccording to the Center for Strategic and International Studies, between 2009 and 2023 more than $230bn (\u00a3181bn) of state support was pumped into the industry.\n\nAs a result its EV industry has become world leading.\n\nThe International Energy Agency says China accounted for more than 60% of the world's new electric car sales last year.\n\nWhile the vast majority of EVs produced in China are sold domestically, overseas markets, and particularly Europe, have become increasingly important.\n\n\"Exports are the profitable segment,\" said Rhodium's senior analyst, Gregor Sebastian.\n\n\"The EU tariffs will hurt China's EV industry because these exports help recover losses from China's domestic price war.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the world's second largest economy is struggling to shake off an economic slowdown in the wake of the pandemic and an ongoing property crisis.\n\nFaced with lower domestic consumption and investment levels, China is trying to \"export its way out\" of the slump, says Alicia Garcia-Herrero, chief economist for the Asia Pacific region at investment bank Natixis.\n\nAnd Beijing is placing yet another large bet on EVs by making the industry one of its \"New Three\" growth drivers - a government blueprint for reviving the economy that also relies on exports of batteries and renewable energy.\n\nHowever, with major markets like the US, the EU and others imposing tariffs and other barriers, it looks like China's latest gamble could deepen trade tensions with some of its largest trading partners.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8207710379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "11:52:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T11:52:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T11:52:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/business/automotive/eu-governments-waver-over-backing-additional-china-ev-tariffs", "title": "EU governments waver over backing additional China EV tariffs", "body": "EU countries are said to be teetering over whether to support additional tariffs on Chinese-built electric vehicles (EVs) highlighting Brussels' challenge in building support for its largest trade case yet as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nGermany, whose carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China, wants to stop the tariffs, according to a government source, while France has been among the firmest backers.\n\nBut a majority of countries are still weighing the pros and cons of the escalating trade spat, according to an informal poll by Reuters of EU governments.\n\nThe issue will be put to members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in a landmark case for the European Commission. The European Union initiated the probe without an industry complaint, the first such trade case of this kind.\n\nThe bloc is set to confirm on Thursday provisional duties of up to 37.6% on Chinese brands such as BYD, Geely and SAIC, as well as on China-made models of Tesla, BMW and other Western automakers.\n\nEU members will also vote in October if the commission proposes multiyear tariffs at the end of its investigation. These would be blocked if a \"qualified majority\" of at least 15 countries representing 65% of the EU population votes against them.\n\nFrance, Italy and Spain, with 40% of the EU population, have indicated they would support tariffs.\n\n\"Europe must defend itself if our companies are harmed and do not compete on equal terms,\" Spain's economy ministry said.\n\nHowever, Czechia, Greece, Ireland and Poland were still debating the issue, official and government sources said, while Belgium has a caretaker government and the Dutch only got a government this week.\n\nGermany has stressed the need for a negotiated solution with Beijing. Its automakers have said tariffs are the wrong approach, with the negative effects outweighing any benefits.\n\nIncreasing the cost of EVs for consumers undermines the EU's goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050, opponents say. Tesla has said it will hike prices.\n\nBeijing's retaliation could bring extra tariffs on EU exports of cognac, pork or luxury cars.\n\nThe commission says duties are needed to counter cheap loans, land and raw materials and other subsidies, and the goal is a level playing field, not shutting Chinese carmakers out, as the U.S.' planned 100% tariff is likely to do.\n\nTariffs could also give the EU leverage in negotiations with Beijing and push producers to make cars in the EU.\n\nHosuk Lee-Makiyama, director of the thinktank, the European Center for International Political Economy, said clear majorities either way could embolden tariff opponents or supporters. He added final positions at the end of the investigation will depend on what Beijing offers in negotiations.\n\n\"If we go to a vote, then it means negotiations have failed,\" he said.\n\nThe EV investigation could be the start for the EU as it toughens its stance on Beijing, as its green and tech companies trail global rivals, interviews with half a dozen trade experts show.\n\nThey point to a 712-page updated report on Chinese state interference and subsidies released in April as the strongest sign yet that Brussels means business.\n\nThe document is by far the most extensive undertaken by the commission, showing it has learned a lesson from an investigation into Chinese solar panels a decade ago when it did not impose tariffs and the EU's own industry collapsed.\n\nIt offers proof to back its assertions that China does not play by the same rules and includes research into a wider range of industries beyond traditional ones such as steel, including semiconductors, telecom equipment and renewable energy.\n\nThat leaves the door open to future cases.\n\n\"This is a report to set the scene and show how and why Europe is changing its policies,\" said Alicia Garcia Herrero, a senior fellow at Brussels-based economic thinktank Bruegel. \"To be frank, it's also a message, especially for the German Chancellery.\"", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "dataType": "news", "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netherlands", "type": "loc", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Netherlands"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Netherlands"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italy", "type": "loc", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Italy"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Italy"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greece", "label": {"eng": "Czech Republic"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Czech Republic"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgium", "type": "loc", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Belgium"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Belgium"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telecommunications", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Telecommunications"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_Chancellery", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "German Chancellery"}}, {"uri":
