"dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 77}], "image": "https://idsb.tmgrup.com.tr/ly/uploads/images/2024/07/03/thumbs/800x531/335205.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9702114", "eventUri": "eng-9702114", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1294117647058823, "wgt": 180, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8209853942", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "16:12:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T16:12:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T16:12:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/renewables/europe-is-slapping-tariffs-on-chinese-electric-vehicles-for-now-heres-what-to-know/articleshow/111494227.cms", "title": "Europe is slapping tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles - for now. Here's what to know", "body": "The European Union is imposing sharply higher customs duties on electric vehicles imported from China. EVs are the latest flash point in a broader trade dispute over Chinese government subsidies and Beijing's burgeoning exports of green technology to the 27-nation bloc. The higher duties go into effect on Friday, pending a final decision in four month's time.\n\nHere are some basic facts about the EU's planned customs duties:\n\nWhat did the European Union do?\n\nAfter an eight-month investigation, the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, found that companies making electric cars in China benefit from massive government help that means they can undercut rivals in the EU on prices, take a big market share and threaten European jobs.\n\nIt announced the higher duties on June 12 and they go into effect from Friday. The duties are provisional, meaning they will be totaled up but won't need to be paid until they're confirmed by a vote of EU governments before November 2.\n\nThe EU will only collect the duties if there's a further finding that the European auto industry would have suffered material harm without them.\n\nThat gives the EU and the Chinese government time to negotiate. Talks have been held between Valdis Dombrovskis, the EU commissioner for the economy, and Chinese Trade Minister Wang Wentao, as well as at the level of technical experts.\n\nThe higher duties are not a goal in themselves but \"a means to correct an imbalance,\" commission spokesman Eric Mamer said Thursday. \"We certainly hope we can come to a solution which would allow us not to have to move forward on this path.\"\n\nThe rates, if applied, would be: 17.4 per cent on cars from BYD, 19.9 per cent on those from Geely and 37.6 per cent for vehicles exported by China's state-owned SAIC.\n\nGeely has brands including Polestar and Sweden's Volvo, while SAIC owns Britain's MG, one of Europe's bestselling EV brands. Other EV manufacturers in China including Western companies such as Volkswagen, BMW and Tesla would be subject to duties of at least 20.8 per cent.\n\nThe commission mentioned that Tesla might get an \"individually calculated\" rate if duties are definitively imposed.\n\nUnder EU rules it's possible - though at present it seems unlikely - that the higher duties could be blocked ahead of the November 2 effective date by vote of what the EU calls a \"qualified majority\" of countries. That means at least 15 of the 27 EU member governments representing at least 65 per cent of the bloc's population.\n\nWhy did the commission take action?\n\nChinese-built electric cars jumped from 3.9 per cent of the EV market in 2020 to 25 per cent by September 2023, the commission said, in part by unfairly undercutting EU industry prices.\n\nThe commission says companies in China accomplished that with the help of subsidies all along the chain of production, from cheap land for factories from local governments to below-market supplies of lithium and batteries from state-owned enterprises to tax breaks and below-interest financing from state-controlled banks.\n\nThe rapid growth in market share has sparked fears that Chinese cars will eventually threaten the EU's ability to produce its own green technology needed to combat climate change, as well as the jobs of 2.5 million workers at risk in the auto industry and 10.3 million more people whose jobs depend indirectly on EV production.\n\nSubsidized solar panels from China have wiped out European producers - an experience that European governments don't want to see repeated with their auto industry.\n\nUnusually, the commission acted on its own, without a complaint from the European auto industry. Industry leaders and Germany, home to BMW, Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz, have been skeptics about the subsidy investigation. That's because many of the cars that will be hit with tariffs are made by European companies, and because China could retaliate against the auto industry or in other areas.\n\nHow do the EU tariffs compare to ones announced by the US?\n\nThe Biden administration is raising tariffs on Chinese EVs to 100 per cent from the current 25 per cent. At that level, the US tariffs block virtually all Chinese EV imports.\n\nThat's not what Europe is trying to do.\n\nEU officials want affordable electric cars from abroad to achieve their goals of cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 55 per cent by 2030 - but without the subsidies EU leaders see as unfair competition\n\nThe planned tariffs are aimed at leveling the playing field by approximating the size of the excess or unfair subsidies available to Chinese carmakers.\n\nEuropean countries subsidize electric cars, too. The question in trade disputes is whether subsidies are fair and available to all carmakers or distort the market in favor of one side.\n\nJust how cheap are Chinese EVs?\n\nChinese carmakers have learned to make electric vehicles cheaply amid ferocious price competition at home in the world's largest car market.\n\nBYD's Seal U Comfort model sells for the equivalent of 21,769 Euros (USD 23,370) in China but 41,990 Euros (SUD 45,078) in Europe, according to Rhodium Group figures.\n\nThe base model of BYD's compact Seagull, due to arrive in Europe next year, sells for the equivalent of around USD 10,000 in China.\n\nWhat does this mean for European drivers and carmakers?\n\nIt's not clear what impact the duties will have on car prices. Chinese carmakers are able to make some cars so cheaply that they could absorb the duties in the form of lower profits instead of raising their prices.\n\nWhile consumers might benefit from cheaper Chinese cars in the short term, allowing unfair practices could eventually mean less competition and higher prices in the long term, the commission argues.\n\nCurrently, Chinese carmakers often sell their vehicles in Europe at much higher prices than the same cars fetch in China, meaning they are favoring profits over market share, even given their recent market gains.\n\nFive of BYD's six models would still earn a profit in Europe even at a 30 per cent tariff, according to Rhodium Group calculations.\n\nThe fear is Europe is that Chinese competitors will turn to lowering their prices closer to the ones they are charging in China. and gain an even bigger chunk of the market.\n\nHow is China likely to react?\n\nBeijing was sharply critical of the higher duties when they were announced, calling them \"a naked act of protectionism.\"\n\nOn Thursday, He Yadong, a spokesperson for the Chinese Commerce Ministry, said that the two sides had held several rounds of technical consultations and noted that a final EU ruling won't be made for four months.\n\n\"It is hoped that the European side and the Chinese side will move in the same direction, show sincerity, expedite the consultation process and reach a mutually acceptable solution as soon as possible on the basis of facts and rules,\" he said at a weekly media briefing in Beijing.\n\nHe also said that China hopes the EU will seriously listen to the voices of the European automakers and governments that have come out against the tariffs and avoid anti-subsidy measures that would harm cooperation between the Chinese and European auto industries.\n\nIt's not clear what agreement might look like. One move could be to agree on minimum prices for Chinese cars.\n\nChina could retaliate against European products such as pork or brandy imports, or against European luxury car imports.\n\nOver the longer term, Chinese carmakers could avoid tariffs by making cars in Europe. BYD is building a plant in Hungary, while Chery has a joint venture to build cars in Spain's Catalonia region. (AP) NPK NPK", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff", "type": {"uri": "2024-07-411390763", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "14:52:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T14:52:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/business/articles/2024-07-04/europe-is-slapping-tariffs-on-chinese-electric-vehicles-for-now-heres-what-to-know", "title": "Europe Is Slapping Tariffs on Chinese Electric Vehicles  --  for Now. Here's What to Know", "body": "FRANKFURT, Germany (AP) -- The European Union is imposing sharply higher customs duties on electric vehicles imported from China. EVs are the latest flash point in a broader trade dispute over Chinese government subsidies and Beijing's burgeoning exports of green technology to the 27-nation bloc.\n\nThe higher duties go into effect on Friday, pending a final decision in four month's time.\n\nHere are some basic facts about the EU's planned customs duties:\n\nWhat did the European Union do?\n\nAfter an eight-month investigation, the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, found that companies making electric cars in China benefit from massive government help that means they can undercut rivals in the EU on prices, take a big market share and threaten European jobs.\n\nIt announced the higher duties on June 12 and they go into effect from Friday. The duties are provisional, meaning they will be totaled up but won't need to be paid until they're confirmed by a vote of EU governments before Nov. 2. The EU will only collect the duties if there's a further finding that the European auto industry would have suffered material harm without them.\n\nThat gives the EU and the Chinese government time to negotiate. Talks have been held between Valdis Dombrovskis, the EU commissioner for the economy, and Chinese Trade Minister Wang Wentao, as well as at the level of technical experts.\n\nThe higher duties are not a goal in themselves but \"a means to correct an imbalance,\" commission spokesman Eric Mamer said Thursday. \"We certainly hope we can come to a solution which would allow us not to have to move forward on this path.\"\n\nThe rates, if applied, would be: 17.4% on cars from BYD, 19.9% on those from Geely and 37.6% for vehicles exported by China's state-owned SAIC. Geely has brands including Polestar and Sweden's Volvo, while SAIC owns Britain's MG, one of Europe's bestselling EV brands. Other EV manufacturers in China including Western companies such as Volkswagen, BMW and Tesla would be subject to duties of at least 20.8%. The commission mentioned that Tesla might get an \"individually calculated\" rate if duties are definitively imposed.\n\nUnder EU rules it's possible -- though at present it seems unlikely -- that the higher duties could be blocked ahead of the Nov. 2 effective date by vote of what the EU calls a \"qualified majority\" of countries. That means at least 15 of the 27 EU member governments representing at least 65% of the bloc's population.\n\nWhy did the commission take action?\n\nChinese-built electric cars jumped from 3.9% of the EV market in 2020 to 25% by September 2023, the commission said, in part by unfairly undercutting EU industry prices.\n\nThe commission says companies in China accomplished that with the help of subsidies all along the chain of production, from cheap land for factories from local governments to below-market supplies of lithium and batteries from state-owned enterprises to tax breaks and below-interest financing from state-controlled banks.\n\nThe rapid growth in market share has sparked fears that Chinese cars will eventually threaten the EU's ability to produce its own green technology needed to combat climate change, as well as the jobs of 2.5 million workers at risk in the auto industry and 10.3 million more people whose jobs depend indirectly on EV production.\n\nSubsidized solar panels from China have wiped out European producers -- an experience that European governments don't want to see repeated with their auto industry.\n\nUnusually, the commission acted on its own, without a complaint from the European auto industry. Industry leaders and Germany, home to BMW, Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz, have been skeptics about the subsidy investigation. That's because many of the cars that will be hit with tariffs are made by European companies, and because China could retaliate against the auto industry or in other areas.\n\nHow do the EU tariffs compare to ones announced by the U.S.?\n\nThe Biden administration is raising tariffs on Chinese EVs to 100% from the current 25%. At that level, the U.S. tariffs block virtually all Chinese EV imports.\n\nThat's not what Europe is trying to do.\n\nEU officials want affordable electric cars from abroad to achieve their goals of cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030 -- but without the subsidies EU leaders see as unfair competition\n\nThe planned tariffs are aimed at leveling the playing field by approximating the size of the excess or unfair subsidies available to Chinese carmakers.\n\nEuropean countries subsidize electric cars, too. The question in trade disputes is whether subsidies are fair and available to all carmakers or distort the market in favor of one side.\n\nJust how cheap are Chinese EVs?\n\nChinese carmakers have learned to make electric vehicles cheaply amid ferocious price competition at home in the world's largest car market.\n\nBYD's Seal U Comfort model sells for the equivalent of 21,769 euros ($23,370) in China but 41,990 euros ($45,078) in Europe, according to Rhodium Group figures. The base model of BYD's compact Seagull, due to arrive in Europe next year, sells for the equivalent of around $10,000 in China.\n\nWhat does this mean for European drivers and carmakers?\n\nIt's not clear what impact the duties will have on car prices. Chinese carmakers are able to make some cars so cheaply that they could absorb the duties in the form of lower profits instead of raising their prices.\n\nWhile consumers might benefit from cheaper Chinese cars in the short term, allowing unfair practices could eventually mean less competition and higher prices in the long term, the commission argues.\n\nCurrently, Chinese carmakers often sell their vehicles in Europe at much higher prices than the same cars fetch in China, meaning they are favoring profits over market share, even given their recent market gains. Five of BYD's six models would still earn a profit in Europe even at a 30% tariff, according to Rhodium Group calculations.\n\nThe fear is Europe is that Chinese competitors will turn to lowering their prices closer to the ones they are charging in China. and gain an even bigger chunk of the market.\n\nHow is China likely to react?\n\nBeijing was sharply critical of the higher duties when they were announced, calling them \"a naked act of protectionism.\"\n\nOn Thursday, He Yadong, a spokesperson for the Chinese Commerce Ministry, said that the two sides had held several rounds of technical consultations and noted that a final EU ruling won't be made for four months.\n\n\"It is hoped that the European side and the Chinese side will move in the same direction, show sincerity, expedite the consultation process and reach a mutually acceptable solution as soon as possible on the basis of facts and rules,\" he said at a weekly media briefing in Beijing.\n\nHe also said that China hopes the EU will seriously listen to the voices of the European automakers and governments that have come out against the tariffs and avoid anti-subsidy measures that would harm cooperation between the Chinese and European auto industries.\n\nIt's not clear what agreement might look like. One move could be to agree on minimum prices for Chinese cars.\n\nChina could retaliate against European products such as pork or brandy imports, or against European luxury car imports.\n\nOver the longer term, Chinese carmakers could avoid tariffs by making cars in Europe. BYD is building a plant in Hungary, while Chery has a joint venture to build cars in Spain's Catalonia region.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Tariff"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsidy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Subsidy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_vehicle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Electric vehicle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_car", "type": {"uri": "8208016660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "14:47:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T14:47:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T14:47:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.kitco.com/news/off-the-wire/2024-07-03/eu-governments-hesitant-chinese-ev-tariffs-trade-spat-escalates", "title": "EU governments hesitant on Chinese EV tariffs as trade spat escalates", "body": "BRUSSELS/LONDON, July 3 (Reuters) - EU countries are wavering over whether to back additional tariffs on Chinese-built electric vehicles, highlighting Brussels' challenge in building support for its largest trade case yet as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nGermany, whose carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China, wants to stop the tariffs, according to a government source, while France has been among the firmest backers.\n\nBut a majority of countries are still weighing the pros and cons of the escalating trade spat, according to an informal poll by Reuters of EU governments.\n\nThe issue will be put to members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in a landmark case for the Commission. The EU initiated the probe without an industry complaint, the first such trade case of this kind.\n\nThe bloc is set to confirm on Thursday provisional duties of up to 37.6% on Chinese brands such as BYD (002594.SZ), Geely (GEELY.UL) and SAIC (600104.SS), as well as on China-made models of Tesla (TSLA.O), BMW (BMWG.DE), and other western automakers.\n\nCarmakers are bracing for billions of dollars in new costs as a result, which analysts say could slow their European expansion.\n\nEU members will also vote in October if the Commission proposes multi-year tariffs at the end of its investigation. These would be blocked if a \"qualified majority\" of at least 15 countries representing 65% of the EU population votes against them.\n\nFrance, Italy and Spain, with 40% of the EU population, have indicated they would back tariffs.\n\n\"Europe must defend itself if our companies are harmed and do not compete on equal terms,\" Spain's economy ministry said.\n\nHowever, the Czech Republic, Greece, Ireland and Poland were still debating the issue, official and government sources said, while Belgium has a caretaker government and the Dutch only got a government this week.\n\nNEGATIVE EFFECTS\n\nGermany has stressed the need for a negotiated solution with Beijing. Its automakers have said tariffs are the wrong approach, with the negative effects outweighing any benefits.\n\nIn a last-ditch effort to influence negotiation, its auto association on Wednesday urged Brussels to drop the tariffs.\n\nIncreasing the cost of EVs for consumers undermines the EU's goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050, opponents say. Tesla has said it will hike prices. Beijing's retaliation could bring extra tariffs on EU exports of cognac, pork or luxury cars.\n\nThe Commission says duties are needed to counter cheap loans, land and raw materials and other subsidies and the goal is a level playing field, not shutting Chinese car makers out, as the United States' planned 100% tariff is likely to do.\n\nTariffs could also give the EU leverage in negotiations with Beijing and push producers to make cars in the EU.\n\nHosuk Lee-Makiyama, director of thinktank the European Centre for International Political Economy, said clear majorities either way could embolden tariff opponents or supporters. He added final positions at the end of the investigation will depend on what Beijing offers in negotiations.\n\n\"If we go to a vote then, it means negotiations have failed,\" he said.\n\nThe EV investigation could just be the start for the EU as it toughens its stance on Beijing, as its green and tech companies trail global rivals, interviews with half a dozen trade experts show.\n\nThey point to a 712-page updated report on Chinese state interference and subsidies released in April as the strongest sign yet that Brussels means business.\n\nThe document is by far the most extensive undertaken by the Commission, showing it has learned a lesson from an investigation into Chinese solar panels a decade ago, when it did not impose tariffs and the EU's own industry collapsed.\n\nIt offers evidence to back its assertions that China does not play by the same rules and includes research into a wider range of industries, beyond traditional ones such as steel, including semiconductors, telecom equipment and renewable energy.\n\nThat leaves the door open to future cases.\n\n\"This is a report to set the scene and show how and why Europe is changing its policies,\" said Alicia Garcia Herrero, a senior fellow at Brussels-based economic thinktank Bruegel. \"To be frank, it's also a message especially for the German chancellery.\"", "source": {"uri": "kitco.com", {"uri": "8209175949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "08:45:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T08:45:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T08:44:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/3005892-eu-china-trade-talks-the-clash-over-electric-vehicles-tariffs", "title": "EU-China Trade Talks: The Clash over Electric Vehicles Tariffs | Business", "body": "China and Europe have been engaged in technical discussions about upcoming tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles. The European Commission plans to impose tariffs up to 37.6% due to concerns over state subsidies. The dispute has caused tension, with China urging EU to consider mutual benefits and avoid further trade measures.\n\nChina and Europe held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on Chinese electric cars that the European Commission is set to confirm on Thursday, China's commerce ministry said at a regular news conference.\n\n\"To date, a number of consultations have been held at the technical level between China and the European Union,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said. \"There is still a four-month window before arbitration, and we hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" he added.\n\nThe Commission is set to confirm provisional import tariffs of up to 37.6% on Chinese-manufactured electric vehicles (EVs), after the bloc accused the world's No.2 economy of providing its firms with heavy state subsidies. EU trade policy has turned increasingly protective over concerns that China's production-focused development model could flood Europe with cheap goods as Chinese firms seek to step up exports amid weak domestic demand.\n\nBeijing rejects accusations that Chinese EVs are unfairly subsidised. \"The governments of some EU member states and some major automobile companies have repeatedly, explicitly opposed the EU's anti-subsidy measures,\" He Yadong said.\n\n\"China hopes the EU will heed the call from within the EU, conduct consultations with China in a rational and pragmatic manner, and avoid countervailing measures hurting the mutually beneficial cooperation and common development of the China-EU auto industry,\" he added. EU countries are wavering over whether to back additional tariffs on Chinese-built EVs, highlighting Brussels' challenge in building support for its largest trade case yet as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nThe issue will be put to the 27-strong bloc in an advisory vote in the coming weeks. Germany, whose carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China, reportedly wants to stop the tariffs, while France has been among the firmest backers.\n\nChina is undertaking an anti-dumping inquiry into European brandy imports. Almost all EU brandy exports to China came from France last year, Chinese customs data shows. Beijing has also opened an anti-dumping investigation into imports of European pork and its by-products, which analysts say is aimed at pressuring Spain, the Netherlands and Denmark to break with the Commission over the curbs.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-409581664", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-03", "time": "06:13:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-03T06:13:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-03T06:08:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://za.investing.com/news/stock-market-news/eu-governments-waver-over-chinese-ev-tariffs-as-trade-spat-escalates-3219040", "title": "EU governments waver over Chinese EV tariffs as trade spat escalates By Reuters", "body": "BRUSSELS (Reuters) - EU countries are wavering over whether to back additional tariffs on Chinese-built electric vehicles, highlighting Brussels' challenge in building support for its largest trade case yet as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nGermany, whose carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China, wants to stop the tariffs, according to a government source, while France has been among the firmest backers.\n\nBut a majority of countries are still weighing the pros and cons of the escalating trade spat, according to an informal poll by Reuters of EU governments.\n\nThe issue will be put to members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in a landmark case for the Commission. The EU initiated the probe without an industry complaint, the first such trade case of this kind.\n\nThe bloc is set to confirm on Thursday provisional duties of up to 37.6% on Chinese brands such as BYD, Geely and SAIC, as well as on China-made models of Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA), BMW (ETR:BMWG) and other western automakers.\n\nEU members will also vote in October if the Commission proposes multi-year tariffs at the end of its investigation. These would be blocked if a \"qualified majority\" if at least 15 countries representing 65% of the EU population votes against them.\n\nFrance, Italy and Spain, with 40% of the EU population, have indicated they would back tariffs.\n\n\"Europe must defend itself if our companies are harmed and do not compete on equal terms,\" Spain's economy ministry said.\n\nHowever, the Czech Republic, Greece, Ireland and Poland were still debating the issue, official and government sources said, while Belgium has a caretaker government and the Dutch only got a government this week.\n\nNEGATIVE EFFECTS\n\nGermany has stressed the need for a negotiated solution with Beijing. Its automakers have said tariffs are the wrong approach, with the negative effects outweighing any benefits.\n\nIncreasing the cost of EVs for consumers undermines the EU's goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050, opponents say. Tesla has said it will hike prices.\n\nBeijing's retaliation could bring extra tariffs on EU exports of cognac, pork or luxury cars.\n\nThe Commission says duties are needed to counter cheap loans, land and raw materials and other subsidies and the goal is a level playing field, not shutting Chinese car makers out, as the United States' planned 100% tariff is likely to do.\n\nTariffs could also give the EU leverage in negotiations with Beijing and push producers to make cars in the EU.\n\nHosuk Lee-Makiyama, director of thinktank the European Centre for International Political Economy, said clear majorities either way could embolden tariff opponents or supporters. He added final positions at the end of the investigation will depend on what Beijing offers in negotiations.\n\n\"If we go to a vote then, it means negotiations have failed,\" he said.\n\nThe EV investigation could just be the start for the EU as it toughens its stance on Beijing, as its green and tech companies trail global rivals, interviews with half a dozen trade experts show.\n\nThey point to a 712-page updated report on Chinese state interference and subsidies released in April as the strongest sign yet that Brussels means business.\n\nThe document is by far the most extensive undertaken by the Commission, showing it has learned a lesson from an investigation into Chinese solar panels a decade ago, when it did not impose tariffs and the EU's own industry collapsed.\n\nIt offers proof to back its assertions that China does not play by the same rules and includes research into a wider range of industries, beyond traditional ones such as steel, including semiconductors, telecom equipment and renewable energy.\n\nThat leaves the door open to future cases.\n\n\"This is a report to set the scene and show how and why Europe is changing its policies,\" said Alicia Garcia {"uri": "8209893196", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "16:43:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T16:43:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T16:42:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://thenextweb.com/news/why-the-eu-is-imposing-maximum-tariffs-of-36-7-on-chinese-evs", "title": "Why the EU is imposing maximum tariffs of 36.7% on Chinese EVs", "body": "The EU today confirmed huge new tariffs for EVs imported from China.\n\nFrom Friday, provisional charges of between 17.4% and 37.6% will apply to the vehicles.\n\nThe lowest level will apply to BYD, an automaker based in Shenzhen. Geely, which owns Volvo, Polestar, and Lotus, faces duties of 19.9%. SAIC, a Chinese state-owned carmaker, will receive the maximum 37.6%.\n\nOther companies will be subject to new tariffs of 20.8%, the weighted average.\n\nThese fees will come on top of a 10% duty that was already in place. As a result, prices of EVs in Europe could increase. Beijing may also impose retaliatory measures.\n\nNonetheless, the EU argues that the intervention is essential.\n\nThe tariffs are an attempt to protect the EU auto industry. Beijing has been accused of creating unfair competition through \"illegal subsidisation\" of Chinese EV makers.\n\nLast October, the EU opened an investigation into the matter.\n\n\"The electric vehicle sector holds huge potential for Europe's future competitiveness and green industrial leadership,\" Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, said at the probe's launch.\n\n\"EU car manufacturers and related sectors are already investing and innovating to fully develop this potential. Wherever we find evidence that their efforts are being impeded by market distortions and unfair competition, we will act decisively.\"\n\nThe EU has now concluded that the subsidies are indeed unfair. With access to this state supports, Chinese EV makers stand accused of artificially lowering prices.\n\nAccording to Brussels, this threatens \"economic injury\" to the bloc's carmakers. But not everyone in the EU supports the new tariffs.\n\nGovernment officials and carmakers have raised several objections to the tariffs.\n\nSweden's prime minister fears the duties will escalate \"a wider trade war.\" Germany's chancellor warned the measures will also harm EU companies that import EVs from China.\n\nHungary, which has forged a strong trade partnership with Beijing, has provided sterner rebukes. \"We disagree with the brutal European punishment of Chinese electric car manufacturers with punitive tariffs,\" the country's economic ministry said last month. \"Protectionism is not the solution.\"\n\nGerman car giant Volkswagen has also slammed the charges. \"The negative effects of this decision outweigh any benefits for the European and especially the German automotive industry,\" a company spokesperson said in a statement.\n\nIndustry analysts have also questioned the EU's plans. James Edmondson, an EV expert at market intelligence firm IDTechEx, fears that the plan will backfire.\n\n\"The long term impact of restricting trade with China more generally could be detrimental to EU manufacturers and adoption of EVs especially when the EU is still so reliant on China for components like EV batteries,\" he told TNW last month.\n\nInevitably, the EU has downplayed these concerns. The bloc's trade chief, Valdis Dombrovskis, said discussions with Beijing could still create a mutually beneficial resolution.", "source": {"uri": "thenextweb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8209371561", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "10:44:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T10:44:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T10:44:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/economy/global-economy/article/3269193/china-eu-trade-reaches-turning-point-ev-tariffs-set-begin-scope-compromise", "title": "Turning point, but 'scope to compromise' for China, EU as EV tariffs loom", "body": "Analysts say provisional import tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles by the European Union represent an \u2018inflection point\u2019 in the relationship\n\nProvisional import tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles by the European Union represent a juncture for the bilateral relationship, but both sides would have enough time to avert \u201ca serious trade war\u201d, analysts said, with the new levies set to take effect on Friday.\n\nThe European Commission confirmed on Thursday that the bloc\u2019s additional duties of up to a revised 37.6 per cent on Chinese battery electric vehicles (BEVs) would begin on Friday and would initially last for a maximum of four months.\n\n\u201cBased on the investigation, the commission has concluded that the BEV value chain in China benefits from unfair subsidisation, which is causing a threat of economic injury to EU BEV producers,\u201d said a commission statement.\n\n\u201cThe investigation has also examined the likely consequences and impact of these measures on importers, users and consumers of BEVs in the EU.\n\n\u201cWithin that time frame, a final decision must be taken on definitive duties, through a vote by EU member states. When adopted, this decision would make the duties definitive for a period of five years.\u201d\n\nTariffs of 17.4 per cent, 19.9 per cent and 37.6 per cent would be applied to Chinese carmakers BYD, Geely and SAIC, respectively, said the statement.\n\nOther BEV producers in China which cooperated in the investigation would be subject to a 20.8 per cent weighted average duty, while the commission set the duty for other non-cooperating companies at 37.6 per cent.We hope that the EU can show its sincerity to progress the communication in the coming four monthsHe Yadong, Ministry of Commerce\n\n\u201cBefore the last result comes out, I believe that both sides still have the space to discuss,\u201d said Liang Ming, director of the foreign trade institute under the Chinese Academy of International Trade and Economic Cooperation, which is a think tank within China\u2019s Ministry of Commerce.\n\nThe EU Commission statement confirmed consultations with the Chinese government had intensified in recent weeks, and that contact would continue at a technical level with a view to reaching a solution which addresses the concerns raised by the European Union.\n\n\u201c[The tariffs are] not a decisive battle, but one of the phases along the lengthy bilateral trade disputes,\u201d said Shanghai-based international relations scholar Shen Dingli.\n\n\u201cBoth sides will continue to contest each other, but they will try to avoid the worst result through negotiation.\u201d\n\nEarlier on Thursday, Ministry of Commerce spokesman He Yadong said that China had expressed its opposition \u201cmany times\u201d towards the EU\u2019s anti-subsidy investigation.\n\n\u201cBoth sides have already held many rounds of negotiations up to now,\u201d he said at a regular press conference in Beijing.\n\n\u201cWe hope that the EU can show its sincerity to progress the dialogue in the coming four months, so that we can find resolutions both sides accept according to facts and rules.\u201d\n\nIn response to the EU\u2019s allegations of subsidies and overcapacity within its electric vehicle (EV) sector, China announced an anti-dumping investigation into certain pork products imported from the EU in June.\n\nChina\u2019s Ministry of Commerce is also reviewing complaints from machinery industry representatives against \u201cbiased practices\u201d from the EU.\n\nFrank Tsai, founder of the Shanghai-based China Crossroads consultancy, described the tariffs on Chinese EVs as \u201can inflection point\u201d in the bilateral relationship.\n\nBeijing would also experience such moves as \u201ca setback to its efforts in the US-EU-China strategic triangle\u201d, added Tsai, who is also an adjunct professor at Emlyon Business School in Shanghai.\n\nBut Tsai also noted that the continuous disengagement of the US towards China would leave the EU the \u201conly one major partner in the advanced West\u201d, meaning Beijing \u201chas thus engaged in a charm offensive to stabilise the EU-China relationship\u201d.\n\nThe tariffs on Chinese EVs represent the first time that the EU Commission has executed its ex officio power to proceed unilaterally without a complaint from the industry.The tariffs are actually hitting their benefits hardRolf Langhammer, Kiel Institute for the World Economy\n\n\u201cThe EU measures announced are carefully tailored and leave plenty of scope to find a compromise \u2026 there is much time until November to find ways out of a serious trade war,\u201d said Rolf Langhammer, a professor with the Germany-based Kiel Institute for the World Economy.\n\nLanghammer noted that the EU Commission was \u201cserious\u201d about its mandate as the only institution lawfully deciding on trade policy issues, even with member states including Germany having different views, as it sees China\u2019s EV subsidies as a \u201cthreat\u201d.\n\nGerman carmakers such as Volkswagen, Mercedes and BMW have opposed the trade barriers proposed by the EU amid fears of a tit-for-tat crackdown on accessing the huge Chinese market, while some other member states, including France, have backed the moves.\n\n\u201cMore than one-third of the exported EVs from China to the EU are produced by the German carmakers,\u201d said Wang Yiwei, a professor of international relations at Renmin University in Beijing.\n\n\u201cSo the tariffs are actually hitting their benefits hard.\u201d\n\nChinese carmakers are also making moves to mitigate the impact of the tariffs, with BYD planning to build its first passenger car facility in Europe in southern Hungary.\n\nChery Automobile also confirmed in April it had also sealed a deal to build its first European factory in Spain in a joint venture with Ebro-EV Motors.\n\nIn 2013, the EU threatened to impose provisional anti-dumping tariffs on Chinese solar panels, but the dispute was resolved after an agreement to set a minimum price after six weeks of talks.\n\n\u201cChina and the EU will still communicate to ensure smooth bilateral trade and investment \u2026 but the issue won\u2019t stop at tariffs,\u201d Wang added.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the entire process of producing EVs that includes digitalisation, software, privacy and other standards.\u201d\n\nHe Weiwen, a senior fellow with the Beijing-based think tank Centre for China and Globalisation, pointed out the interdependence between both sides.\n\nHe cited the fact that EU law would require all new cars entering the market as of 2035 to have zero carbon dioxide emissions, and \u201cthey can\u2019t attain the goal only by themselves\u201d.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "South China Morning Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle", "https://cdn.i-scmp.com/sites/default/files/styles/1280x720/public/d8/video/thumbnail/2024/06/13/clean-thumb-(3).jpg?itok=jbUsLfgq", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9702114", "eventUri": {"uri": "8209723552", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "14:38:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T14:38:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T14:37:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/chinese-ap-europe-china-european-union-b2574031.html", "title": "Europe is slapping tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles  --  for now. Here's what to know", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nThe European Union is imposing sharply higher customs duties on electric vehicles imported from China. EVs are the latest flash point in a broader trade dispute over Chinese government subsidies and Beijing's burgeoning exports of green technology to the 27-nation bloc.\n\nThe higher duties go into effect on Friday, pending a final decision in four month's time.\n\nHere are some basic facts about the EU's planned customs duties:\n\nWhat did the European Union do?\n\nAfter an eight-month investigation, the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, found that companies making electric cars in China benefit from massive government help that means they can undercut rivals in the EU on prices, take a big market share and threaten European jobs.\n\nIt announced the higher duties on June 12 and they go into effect from Friday. The duties are provisional, meaning they will be totaled up but won't need to be paid until they're confirmed by a vote of EU governments before Nov. 2. The EU will only collect the duties if there's a further finding that the European auto industry would have suffered material harm without them.\n\nThat gives the EU and the Chinese government time to negotiate. Talks have been held between Valdis Dombrovskis, the EU commissioner for the economy, and Chinese Trade Minister Wang Wentao, as well as at the level of technical experts.\n\nThe higher duties are not a goal in themselves but \"a means to correct an imbalance,\" commission spokesman Eric Mamer said Thursday. \"We certainly hope we can come to a solution which would allow us not to have to move forward on this path.\"\n\nThe rates, if applied, would be: 17.4% on cars from BYD, 19.9% on those from Geely and 37.6% for vehicles exported by China's state-owned SAIC. Geely has brands including Polestar and Sweden's Volvo, while SAIC owns Britain's MG, one of Europe's bestselling EV brands. Other EV manufacturers in China including Western companies such as Volkswagen, BMW and Tesla would be subject to duties of at least 20.8%. The commission mentioned that Tesla might get an \"individually calculated\" rate if duties are definitively imposed.\n\nUnder EU rules it's possible -- though at present it seems unlikely -- that the higher duties could be blocked ahead of the Nov. 2 effective date by vote of what the EU calls a \"qualified majority\" of countries. That means at least 15 of the 27 EU member governments representing at least 65% of the bloc's population.\n\nWhy did the commission take action?\n\nChinese-built electric cars jumped from 3.9% of the EV market in 2020 to 25% by September 2023, the commission said, in part by unfairly undercutting EU industry prices.\n\nThe commission says companies in China accomplished that with the help of subsidies all along the chain of production, from cheap land for factories from local governments to below-market supplies of lithium and batteries from state-owned enterprises to tax breaks and below-interest financing from state-controlled banks.\n\nThe rapid growth in market share has sparked fears that Chinese cars will eventually threaten the EU's ability to produce its own green technology needed to combat climate change, as well as the jobs of 2.5 million workers at risk in the auto industry and 10.3 million more people whose jobs depend indirectly on EV production.\n\nSubsidized solar panels from China have wiped out European producers -- an experience that European governments don't want to see repeated with their auto industry.\n\nUnusually, the commission acted on its own, without a complaint from the European auto industry. Industry leaders and Germany, home to BMW, Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz, have been skeptics about the subsidy investigation. That's because many of the cars that will be hit with tariffs are made by European companies, and because China could retaliate against the auto industry or in other areas.\n\nHow do the EU tariffs compare to ones announced by the U.S.?\n\nThe Biden administration is raising tariffs on Chinese EVs to 100% from the current 25%. At that level, the U.S. tariffs block virtually all Chinese EV imports.\n\nThat's not what Europe is trying to do.\n\nEU officials want affordable electric cars from abroad to achieve their goals of cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030 -- but without the subsidies EU leaders see as unfair competition\n\nThe planned tariffs are aimed at leveling the playing field by approximating the size of the excess or unfair subsidies available to Chinese carmakers.\n\nEuropean countries subsidize electric cars, too. The question in trade disputes is whether subsidies are fair and available to all carmakers or distort the market in favor of one side.\n\nJust how cheap are Chinese EVs?\n\nChinese carmakers have learned to make electric vehicles cheaply amid ferocious price competition at home in the world's largest car market.\n\nBYD's Seal U Comfort model sells for the equivalent of 21,769 euros ($23,370) in China but 41,990 euros ($45,078) in Europe, according to Rhodium Group figures. The base model of BYD's compact Seagull, due to arrive in Europe next year, sells for the equivalent of around $10,000 in China.\n\nWhat does this mean for European drivers and carmakers?\n\nIt's not clear what impact the duties will have on car prices. Chinese carmakers are able to make some cars so cheaply that they could absorb the duties in the form of lower profits instead of raising their prices.\n\nWhile consumers might benefit from cheaper Chinese cars in the short term, allowing unfair practices could eventually mean less competition and higher prices in the long term, the commission argues.\n\nCurrently, Chinese carmakers often sell their vehicles in Europe at much higher prices than the same cars fetch in China, meaning they are favoring profits over market share, even given their recent market gains. Five of BYD's six models would still earn a profit in Europe even at a 30% tariff, according to Rhodium Group calculations.\n\nThe fear is Europe is that Chinese competitors will turn to lowering their prices closer to the ones they are charging in China. and gain an even bigger chunk of the market.\n\nHow is China likely to react?\n\nBeijing was sharply critical of the higher duties when they were announced, calling them \"a naked act of protectionism.\"\n\nOn Thursday, He Yadong, a spokesperson for the Chinese Commerce Ministry, said that the two sides had held several rounds of technical consultations and noted that a final EU ruling won't be made for four months.\n\n\"It is hoped that the European side and the Chinese side will move in the same direction, show sincerity, expedite the consultation process and reach a mutually acceptable solution as soon as possible on the basis of facts and rules,\" he said at a weekly media briefing in Beijing.\n\nHe also said that China hopes the EU will seriously listen to the voices of the European automakers and governments that have come out against the tariffs and avoid anti-subsidy measures that would harm cooperation between the Chinese and European auto industries.\n\nIt's not clear what agreement might look like. One move could be to agree on minimum prices for Chinese cars.\n\nChina could retaliate against European products such as pork or brandy imports, or against European luxury car imports.\n\nOver the longer term, Chinese carmakers could avoid tariffs by making cars in Europe. BYD is building a plant in Hungary, while Chery has a joint venture to build cars in Spain's Catalonia region.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, Here's what to know", "body": "FRANKFURT, Germany (AP) -- The European Union is imposing sharply higher customs duties on electric vehicles imported from China. EVs are the latest flash point in a broader trade dispute over Chinese government subsidies and Beijing's burgeoning exports of green technology to the 27-nation bloc.\n\nThe higher duties go into effect on Friday, pending a final decision in four month's time.\n\nHere are some basic facts about the EU's planned customs duties:\n\nAfter an eight-month investigation, the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, found that companies making electric cars in China benefit from massive government help that means they can undercut rivals in the EU on prices, take a big market share and threaten European jobs.\n\nIt announced the higher duties on June 12 and they go into effect from Friday. The duties are provisional, meaning they will be totaled up but won't need to be paid until they're confirmed by a vote of EU governments before Nov. 2. The EU will only collect the duties if there's a further finding that the European auto industry would have suffered material harm without them.\n\nThat gives the EU and the Chinese government time to negotiate. Talks have been held between Valdis Dombrovskis, the EU commissioner for the economy, and Chinese Trade Minister Wang Wentao, as well as at the level of technical experts.\n\nThe higher duties are not a goal in themselves but \"a means to correct an imbalance,\" commission spokesman Eric Mamer said Thursday. \"We certainly hope we can come to a solution which would allow us not to have to move forward on this path.\"\n\nThe rates, if applied, would be: 17.4% on cars from BYD, 19.9% on those from Geely and 37.6% for vehicles exported by China's state-owned SAIC. Geely has brands including Polestar and Sweden's Volvo, while SAIC owns Britain's MG, one of Europe's bestselling EV brands. Other EV manufacturers in China including Western companies such as Volkswagen, BMW and Tesla would be subject to duties of at least 20.8%. The commission mentioned that Tesla might get an \"individually calculated\" rate if duties are definitively imposed.\n\nUnder EU rules it's possible -- though at present it seems unlikely -- that the higher duties could be blocked ahead of the Nov. 2 effective date by vote of what the EU calls a \"qualified majority\" of countries. That means at least 15 of the 27 EU member governments representing at least 65% of the bloc's population.\n\nChinese-built electric cars jumped from 3.9% of the EV market in 2020 to 25% by September 2023, the commission said, in part by unfairly undercutting EU industry prices.\n\nThe commission says companies in China accomplished that with the help of subsidies all along the chain of production, from cheap land for factories from local governments to below-market supplies of lithium and batteries from state-owned enterprises to tax breaks and below-interest financing from state-controlled banks.\n\nThe rapid growth in market share has sparked fears that Chinese cars will eventually threaten the EU's ability to produce its own green technology needed to combat climate change, as well as the jobs of 2.5 million workers at risk in the auto industry and 10.3 million more people whose jobs depend indirectly on EV production.\n\nSubsidized solar panels from China have wiped out European producers -- an experience that European governments don't want to see repeated with their auto industry.\n\nUnusually, the commission acted on its own, without a complaint from the European auto industry. Industry leaders and Germany, home to BMW, Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz, have been skeptics about the subsidy investigation. That's because many of the cars that will be hit with tariffs are made by European companies, and because China could retaliate against the auto industry or in other areas.\n\nThe Biden administration is raising tariffs on Chinese EVs to 100% from the current 25%. At that level, the U.S. tariffs block virtually all Chinese EV imports.\n\nThat's not what Europe is trying to do.\n\nEU officials want affordable electric cars from abroad to achieve their goals of cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030 -- but without the subsidies EU leaders see as unfair competition\n\nThe planned tariffs are aimed at leveling the playing field by approximating the size of the excess or unfair subsidies available to Chinese carmakers.\n\nEuropean countries subsidize electric cars, too. The question in trade disputes is whether subsidies are fair and available to all carmakers or distort the market in favor of one side.\n\nChinese carmakers have learned to make electric vehicles cheaply amid ferocious price competition at home in the world's largest car market.\n\nBYD's Seal U Comfort model sells for the equivalent of 21,769 euros ($23,370) in China but 41,990 euros ($45,078) in Europe, according to Rhodium Group figures. The base model of BYD's compact Seagull, due to arrive in Europe next year, sells for the equivalent of around $10,000 in China.\n\nIt's not clear what impact the duties will have on car prices. Chinese carmakers are able to make some cars so cheaply that they could absorb the duties in the form of lower profits instead of raising their prices.\n\nWhile consumers might benefit from cheaper Chinese cars in the short term, allowing unfair practices could eventually mean less competition and higher prices in the long term, the commission argues.\n\nCurrently, Chinese carmakers often sell their vehicles in Europe at much higher prices than the same cars fetch in China, meaning they are favoring profits over market share, even given their recent market gains. Five of BYD's six models would still earn a profit in Europe even at a 30% tariff, according to Rhodium Group calculations.\n\nThe fear is Europe is that Chinese competitors will turn to lowering their prices closer to the ones they are charging in China. and gain an even bigger chunk of the market.\n\nBeijing was sharply critical of the higher duties when they were announced, calling them \"a naked act of protectionism.\"\n\nOn Thursday, He Yadong, a spokesperson for the Chinese Commerce Ministry, said that the two sides had held several rounds of technical consultations and noted that a final EU ruling won't be made for four months.\n\n\"It is hoped that the European side and the Chinese side will move in the same direction, show sincerity, expedite the consultation process and reach a mutually acceptable solution as soon as possible on the basis of facts and rules,\" he said at a weekly media briefing in Beijing.\n\nHe also said that China hopes the EU will seriously listen to the voices of the European automakers and governments that have come out against the tariffs and avoid anti-subsidy measures that would harm cooperation between the Chinese and European auto industries.\n\nIt's not clear what agreement might look like. One move could be to agree on minimum prices for Chinese cars.\n\nChina could retaliate against European products such as pork or brandy imports, or against European luxury car imports.\n\nOver the longer term, Chinese carmakers could avoid tariffs by making cars in Europe. "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.autonews.com/china/germany-among-eu-govts-wavering-over-china-ev-tariffs", "title": "EU gov'ts waver over Chinese EV tariffs as trade spat escalates", "body": "BRUSSELS -- EU countries are wavering over whether to back additional tariffs on Chinese-built electric vehicles, highlighting Brussels' challenge in building support for its largest trade case yet as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nGermany, whose automakers made a third of their sales last year in China, wants to stop the tariffs, according to a government source, while France has been among the firmest backers.\n\nBut a majority of countries are still weighing the pros and cons of the escalating trade spat, according to an informal poll by Reuters of EU governments.\n\nThe issue will be put to members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks, the first official test of support in a landmark case for the Commission.\n\nThe EU initiated the probe without an industry complaint, the first such trade case of this kind.\n\nThe bloc is set to confirm on Thursday provisional duties of up to 37.6 percent on Chinese brands such as BYD, Geely and SAIC, as well as on China-made models of Tesla, BMW and other western automakers.\n\nEU members will also vote in October if the Commission proposes multi-year tariffs at the end of its investigation.\n\nThese would be blocked if a \"qualified majority\" if at least 15 countries representing 65 percent of the EU population votes against them.\n\nFrance, Italy and Spain, with 40 percent of the EU population, have indicated they would back tariffs.\n\n\"Europe must defend itself if our companies are harmed and do not compete on equal terms,\" Spain's economy ministry said.\n\nHowever, the Czech Republic, Greece, Ireland and Poland were still debating the issue, official and government sources said, while Belgium has a caretaker government and the Dutch only got a government this week.\n\nNegative effects\n\nGermany has stressed the need for a negotiated solution with Beijing. Its automakers have said tariffs are the wrong approach, with the negative effects outweighing any benefits.\n\nIncreasing the cost of EVs for consumers undermines the EU's goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050, opponents say. Tesla has said it will hike prices.\n\nBeijing's retaliation could bring extra tariffs on EU exports of cognac, pork or luxury cars.\n\nThe Commission says duties are needed to counter cheap loans, land and raw materials and other subsidies and the goal is a level playing field, not shutting Chinese automakers out, as the U.S.'s planned 100 percent tariff is likely to do.\n\nTariffs could also give the EU leverage in negotiations with Beijing and push producers to make cars in the EU.\n\nHosuk Lee-Makiyama, director of thinktank the European Centre for International Political Economy, said clear majorities either way could embolden tariff opponents or supporters. He added final positions at the end of the investigation will depend on what Beijing offers in negotiations.\n\n\"If we go to a vote then, it means negotiations have failed,\" he said.\n\nThe EV investigation could just be the start for the EU as it toughens its stance on Beijing, as its green and tech companies trail global rivals, interviews with half a dozen trade experts show.\n\nCHINA NEWSLETTER: Sign up for commentary by journalist Yang Jian and highlights from top manufacturer and supplier news from China, delivered on Thursdays.\n\nEmail Address\n\nThey point to a 712-page updated report on Chinese state interference and subsidies released in April as the strongest sign yet that Brussels means business.\n\nThe document is by far the most extensive undertaken by the Commission, showing it has learned a lesson from an investigation into Chinese solar panels a decade ago, when it did not impose tariffs and the EU's own industry collapsed.\n\nIt offers proof to back its assertions that China does not play by the same rules and includes research into a wider range of industries, beyond traditional ones such as steel, including semiconductors, telecom equipment and renewable energy.\n\nThat leaves the door open to future cases.\n\n\"This is a report to set the scene and show how and why Europe is changing its policies,\" said Alicia Garcia Herrero, a senior fellow at Brussels-based economic thinktank Bruegel. \"To be frank, it's also a message especially for the German chancellery.\"", "source": {"uri": "autonews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8209783469", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "15:21:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T15:21:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T15:19:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-europe-is-slapping-tariffs-on-chinese-electric-vehicles-for-now-heres-what-to-know-6086727.html", "title": "World News | Europe is Slapping Tariffs on Chinese Electric Vehicles  --  for Now. Here's What to Know | LatestLY", "body": "Frankfurt, Jul 4 (AP) The European Union is imposing sharply higher customs duties on electric vehicles imported from China. EVs are the latest flash point in a broader trade dispute over Chinese government subsidies and Beijing's burgeoning exports of green technology to the 27-nation bloc.\n\nThe higher duties go into effect on Friday, pending a final decision in four month's time.\n\nAlso Read | Australia-India Strategic Research Fund: 5 Indian Institutions Receive Grants for Their Projects Including for AI, Machines Learning, Biotech and More Under AISRF.\n\nHere are some basic facts about the EU's planned customs duties:\n\nAlso Read | UKG Layoffs: US-Based Software Firm Announces Massive Layoff Round, Cuts Over 2,200 Jobs as Part of Organisational Changes To Focus on Growth Areas.\n\nWhat did the European Union do?\n\nAfter an eight-month investigation, the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, found that companies making electric cars in China benefit from massive government help that means they can undercut rivals in the EU on prices, take a big market share and threaten European jobs.\n\nIt announced the higher duties on June 12 and they go into effect from Friday. The duties are provisional, meaning they will be totaled up but won't need to be paid until they're confirmed by a vote of EU governments before November 2.\n\nThe EU will only collect the duties if there's a further finding that the European auto industry would have suffered material harm without them.\n\nThat gives the EU and the Chinese government time to negotiate. Talks have been held between Valdis Dombrovskis, the EU commissioner for the economy, and Chinese Trade Minister Wang Wentao, as well as at the level of technical experts.\n\nThe higher duties are not a goal in themselves but \"a means to correct an imbalance,\" commission spokesman Eric Mamer said Thursday. \"We certainly hope we can come to a solution which would allow us not to have to move forward on this path.\"\n\nThe rates, if applied, would be: 17.4 per cent on cars from BYD, 19.9 per cent on those from Geely and 37.6 per cent for vehicles exported by China's state-owned SAIC.\n\nGeely has brands including Polestar and Sweden's Volvo, while SAIC owns Britain's MG, one of Europe's bestselling EV brands. Other EV manufacturers in China including Western companies such as Volkswagen, BMW and Tesla would be subject to duties of at least 20.8 per cent.\n\nThe commission mentioned that Tesla might get an \"individually calculated\" rate if duties are definitively imposed.\n\nUnder EU rules it's possible -- though at present it seems unlikely -- that the higher duties could be blocked ahead of the November 2 effective date by vote of what the EU calls a \"qualified majority\" of countries. That means at least 15 of the 27 EU member governments representing at least 65 per cent of the bloc's population.\n\nWhy did the commission take action?\n\nChinese-built electric cars jumped from 3.9 per cent of the EV market in 2020 to 25 per cent by September 2023, the commission said, in part by unfairly undercutting EU industry prices.\n\nThe commission says companies in China accomplished that with the help of subsidies all along the chain of production, from cheap land for factories from local governments to below-market supplies of lithium and batteries from state-owned enterprises to tax breaks and below-interest financing from state-controlled banks.\n\nThe rapid growth in market share has sparked fears that Chinese cars will eventually threaten the EU's ability to produce its own green technology needed to combat climate change, as well as the jobs of 2.5 million workers at risk in the auto industry and 10.3 million more people whose jobs depend indirectly on EV production.\n\nSubsidized solar panels from China have wiped out European producers -- an experience that European governments don't want to see repeated with their auto industry.\n\nUnusually, the commission acted on its own, without a complaint from the European auto industry. Industry leaders and Germany, home to BMW, Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz, have been skeptics about the subsidy investigation. That's because many of the cars that will be hit with tariffs are made by European companies, and because China could retaliate against the auto industry or in other areas.\n\nHow do the EU tariffs compare to ones announced by the US?\n\nThe Biden administration is raising tariffs on Chinese EVs to 100 per cent from the current 25 per cent. At that level, the US tariffs block virtually all Chinese EV imports.\n\nThat's not what Europe is trying to do.\n\nEU officials want affordable electric cars from abroad to achieve their goals of cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 55 per cent by 2030 -- but without the subsidies EU leaders see as unfair competition\n\nThe planned tariffs are aimed at leveling the playing field by approximating the size of the excess or unfair subsidies available to Chinese carmakers.\n\nEuropean countries subsidize electric cars, too. The question in trade disputes is whether subsidies are fair and available to all carmakers or distort the market in favor of one side.\n\nJust how cheap are Chinese EVs?\n\nChinese carmakers have learned to make electric vehicles cheaply amid ferocious price competition at home in the world's largest car market.\n\nBYD's Seal U Comfort model sells for the equivalent of 21,769 Euros (USD 23,370) in China but 41,990 Euros (SUD 45,078) in Europe, according to Rhodium Group figures.\n\nThe base model of BYD's compact Seagull, due to arrive in Europe next year, sells for the equivalent of around USD 10,000 in China.\n\nWhat does this mean for European drivers and carmakers?\n\nIt's not clear what impact the duties will have on car prices. Chinese carmakers are able to make some cars so cheaply that they could absorb the duties in the form of lower profits instead of raising their prices.\n\nWhile consumers might benefit from cheaper Chinese cars in the short term, allowing unfair practices could eventually mean less competition and higher prices in the long term, the commission argues.\n\nCurrently, Chinese carmakers often sell their vehicles in Europe at much higher prices than the same cars fetch in China, meaning they are favoring profits over market share, even given their recent market gains.\n\nFive of BYD's six models would still earn a profit in Europe even at a 30 per cent tariff, according to Rhodium Group calculations.\n\nThe fear is Europe is that Chinese competitors will turn to lowering their prices closer to the ones they are charging in China. and gain an even bigger chunk of the market.\n\nHow is China likely to react?\n\nBeijing was sharply critical of the higher duties when they were announced, calling them \"a naked act of protectionism.\"\n\nOn Thursday, He Yadong, a spokesperson for the Chinese Commerce Ministry, said that the two sides had held several rounds of technical consultations and noted that a final EU ruling won't be made for four months.\n\n\"It is hoped that the European side and the Chinese side will move in the same direction, show sincerity, expedite the consultation process and reach a mutually acceptable solution as soon as possible on the basis of facts and rules,\" he said at a weekly media briefing in Beijing.\n\nHe also said that China hopes the EU will seriously listen to the voices of the European automakers and governments that have come out against the tariffs and avoid anti-subsidy measures that would harm cooperation between the Chinese and European auto industries.\n\nIt's not clear what agreement might look like. One move could be to agree on minimum prices for Chinese cars.\n\nChina could retaliate against European products such as pork or brandy imports, or against European luxury car imports.\n\nOver the longer term, Chinese carmakers could avoid tariffs by making cars in Europe. BYD is building a plant in Hungary, while Chery has a joint venture to build cars in Spain's Catalonia region. {"uri": "8209477698", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "11:52:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T11:52:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T11:52:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/business/2024/07/04/eu-moves-ahead-with-provisional-tariffs-on-china-ev-imports/", "title": "EU moves ahead with provisional tariffs on China EV imports", "body": "The European Union moved ahead with plans to impose provisional tariffs on the imports of electric vehicles made in China that would raise rates to as high as 48 per cent, a step likely to escalate trade tensions with Beijing.\n\nThe EU confirmed in a news release Thursday that under its anti-subsidy investigation, it would apply provisional duties on three Chinese manufacturers that were sampled for the investigation. MG maker SAIC faces a 37.6 per cent tariff on top of the existing 10 per cent rate, while Volvo owner Geely and BYD will be hit with additional charges of 19.9 per cent and 17.4 per cent, respectively.\n\nOther EV producers in China that co-operated with the investigation but have not been sampled will be subject to a weighted average duty of 20.8 per cent, while firms that didn't co-operate will face an additional 37.6 per cent levy.\n\nThe provisional duties will apply as of Friday, and definitive duties would kick in by November unless the two sides come to some kind of alternative solution or a qualified majority of EU member states block the final move. Tesla may receive an individually calculated duty rate at that definitive stage following a request to be sampled.\n\nThe EU, which said that talks with China have intensified in recent weeks, said the probe concluded that China subsidises its EV industry to a degree that causes economic harm to the bloc's carmakers.\n\n\"Those talks with China are ongoing,\" Valdis Dombrovskis, an executive vice-president of the European Commission, said in an interview. \"Should a mutually beneficial solution emerge, we can also find ways then not to apply at the end of the day the definitive tariffs. but it's very clear that this solution needs to resolve this market distortion we're currently having.\"\n\nChina has threatened to retaliate and has already launched a targeted anti-dumping probe on pork imports. The findings of an investigation into EU spirits are due early next year but could come anytime, based on what's happened before. Beijing has warned it could hit European agricultural goods, aviation and cars with large engines. China could also decide to challenge the EU's probe at the World Trade Organization.\n\n\"We are not seeing the basis for retaliation as what we are conducting is indeed in line with WTO rules,\" Dombrovskis said.\n\nThe EU and China have been consulting on a way forward and the two sides plan to continue conversations over the next four months.\n\nFor Brussels, any solution has to be grounded in WTO rules and address the underlying harmful subsidies the probe has identified. Beijing has looked to transform the investigation into a negotiation and has been trying to divide member states by pressuring them bilaterally, Bloomberg previously reported. Some member states, including Germany, have been pushing for a negotiated compromise.\n\nIn talks between the two sides, China had asked the EU not to introduce the provisional measures at all - or to consider lower rates based on fewer criteria and then increase them in November if a solution couldn't be found before definitive tariffs are due, according to people familiar with the matter.\n\nBeijing has also asked whether the rates can be adjusted between now and November if the situation changes as the two sides continue to talk, the people said. Though rates can be tweaked during the process, the EU's preference is to first establish a common understanding of the facts before exploring a mutually agreed solution that adheres to WTO rules, they added.\n\nTechnical talks between the two sides will resume in the coming days, the people added.\n\nThe provisional duties are being introduced by a guarantee, and would be collected only if and when definitive duties are imposed, the EU said in a statement last month. The EU is expected to issue guidance on the form the guarantees will take.\n\nGeely and BYD declined to comment on the provisional tariffs going into effect. SAIC didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe tariffs will likely cut imports from China by a quarter, amounting to a value of roughly $4 billion, according to an estimate by Moritz Schularick, president of Germany's Kiel Institute for the World Economy.\n\nMany European carmakers have made clear they're opposed to higher tariffs, with companies like Mercedes-Benz Group and Volkswagen warning against them. China is the biggest market for Mercedes, VW and BMW.\n\nBMW CEO Oliver Zipse said the tariffs are a \"dead end\" and won't strengthen European carmakers.\n\n\"On the contrary: It not only harms the business model of globally active companies, it also limits the supply of electric cars to European customers and can therefore even slow down decarbonisation in the transport sector,\" he said in a statement. - Bloomberg", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff", "type": "wiki", counties are divided over whether to back the bloc's new tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles.\n\nA government source said Germany wants to stop the duties altogether.\n\nIts carmakers made a third of their sales last year in China.\n\nAnd a leading auto industry group from the country urged the EU to back down Wednesday.\n\nBut fellow European powerhouse France has been among the strongest supporters of the tariffs.\n\nAnd a poll by Reuters showed a majority of countries are still weighing the pros and cons of the trade fall-out.\n\nThe issue will be put to EU members in an advisory vote in the coming weeks.\n\nThe bloc is due to confirm on Thursday provisional duties of up to 37.6% on Chinese EV-makers like BYD.\n\nChina-made models from western automakers, like Tesla and BMW, will also be hit.\n\nEU members will then vote in October if the Commission proposes multi-year tariffs at the end of its investigation.\n\nBut these would be blocked if at least 15 countries representing 65% of the EU population votes against them.\n\nFrance, Italy and Spain, with 40% of the EU population, have indicated they would support tariffs.\n\nWhile sources say others like Poland and Greece are still debating the issue.\n\nThe Commission says the aim of the duties is to level the playing field, rather than shut Chinese automakers out.\n\nIt wants to counter cheap loans, land, raw materials and other subsidies.\n\nSupporters also believe tariffs could give the EU leverage in negotiations with Beijing and push producers to make cars in the EU.\n\nBut there is concern over {"uri": "8209687898", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-04", "time": "14:12:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-04T14:12:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-04T14:12:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/business/european-union-china-ev-trade-duties-tariffs-eu-imports-electric-vehicles-4457251", "title": "China-built EVs hit with duties in biggest EU trade case yet", "body": "BRUSSELS: The European Union will impose tariffs of up to 37.6 per cent from Friday (Jul 5) on imports of electric vehicles made in China, EU officials said, ratcheting up tensions with Beijing in Brussels' largest trade case yet.\n\nThere is however a four-month window during which the tariffs are provisional and intensive talks are expected to continue between the two sides as Beijing threatens wide-ranging retaliation.\n\nThe European Commission's provisional duties of between 17.4 per cent and 37.6 per cent without backdating are designed to prevent what its president Ursula von der Leyen has said is a threatened flood of cheap EVs built with state subsidies.\n\nThe rates, laid out in a 208-page document published on Thursday, are almost the same as those announced by the Commission on Jun 12. The executive made adjustments after companies identified minor calculation errors in the initial disclosure.\n\nBeijing said then it would take \"all necessary measures\" to safeguard China's interests.\n\nThese could include retaliatory tariffs on exports to China of products such as cognac or pork.\n\nEU trade chief Valdis Dombrovskis said there is no basis for China to retaliate.\n\n\"Our aim is to ... ensure fair competition and a level playing field,\" he said in an interview with Bloomberg.\n\nThe EU anti-subsidy investigation has nearly four more months to run.\n\nAt the end of it, the Commission, the EU's executive arm, could propose definitive duties, typically applying for five years, on which EU members would vote.\n\n\"Those talks with China are ongoing and indeed should a mutually beneficial solution emerge, we can also find ways not to apply at the end of the day the tariffs,\" Dombrovskis said.\n\n\"But it is very clear this solution (would) need to solve that market distortion that we are currently having ... and it needs to be market compliant.\"\n\nChina's commerce ministry said on Thursday both sides have so far held several rounds of technical talks over tariffs on the issue.\n\n\"We hope that the European and Chinese sides will move in the same direction, show sincerity, and push forward with the consultation process as soon as possible,\" He Yadong, a ministry spokesperson, said.\n\nBYD faces duties of 17.4 per cent, Geely 19.9 per cent and SAIC 37.6 per cent, the EU said on Thursday. These are on top of the EU's standard 10 per cent duty on car imports.\n\nCompanies deemed to have cooperated with the anti-subsidy investigation, including western carmakers Tesla and BMW, will be subject to 20.8 per cent tariffs and those that did not cooperate a rate of 37.6 per cent.", "source": {"uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNA"}, "authors": [], "concepts":
